poem.verse: 9I will say to God, my rock,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Why have you forgotten me?
Why must I go about in sorrow
because of the enemy’s oppression? ’

poem.verse: 10My adversaries taunt me,

poetryblock.poem: as if crushing my bones,
while all day long they say to me,
‘Where is your God? ’

poem.verse: 11Why, my soul, are you so dejected?

poetryblock.poem: Why are you in such turmoil?
Put your hope in God, for I will still praise him,
my Saviour and my God.

poem.verse: 1Vindicate me, God, and champion my cause

poetryblock.poem: against an unfaithful nation;
rescue me from the deceitful and unjust person.

poem.verse: 2For you are the God of my refuge.

poetryblock.poem: Why have you rejected me?
Why must I go about in sorrow
because of the enemy’s oppression?

poem.verse: 3Send your light and your truth; let them lead me.

poetryblock.poem: Let them bring me to your holy mountain,
to your dwelling place.

poem.verse: 4Then I will come to the altar of God,

poetryblock.poem: to God, my greatest joy.
I will praise you with the lyre,
God, my God.

poem.verse: 5Why, my soul, are you so dejected?

poetryblock.poem: Why are you in such turmoil?
Put your hope in God, for I will still praise him,
my Saviour and my God.

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A 'Maskil' of the sons of Korah.

poem.verse: 1God, we have heard with our ears –

poetryblock.poem: our ancestors have told us –
the work you accomplished in their days,
in days long ago:

poem.verse: 2In order to plant them,

poetryblock.poem: you displaced the nations by your hand;
in order to settle them,
you brought disaster on the peoples.

poem.verse: 3For they did not take the land by their sword –

poetryblock.poem: their arm did not bring them victory –
but by your right hand, your arm,
and the light of your face,
because you were favourable towards them.

poem.verse: 4You are my King, my God,

poetryblock.poem: who ordains victories for Jacob.

poem.verse: 5Through you we drive back our foes;

poetryblock.poem: through your name we trample our enemies.

poem.verse: 6For I do not trust in my bow,

poetryblock.poem: and my sword does not bring me victory.

poem.verse: 7But you give us victory over our foes

poetryblock.poem: and let those who hate us be disgraced.

poem.verse: 8We boast in God all day long;

poetryblock.poem: we will praise your name for ever.'Selah'

poem.verse: 9But you have rejected and humiliated us;

poetryblock.poem: you do not march out with our armies.

poem.verse: 10You make us retreat from the foe,

poetryblock.poem: and those who hate us
have taken plunder for themselves.

poem.verse: 11You hand us over to be eaten like sheep

poetryblock.poem: and scatter us among the nations.

poem.verse: 12You sell your people for nothing;

poetryblock.poem: you make no profit from selling them.

poem.verse: 13You make us an object of reproach to our neighbours,

poetryblock.poem: a source of mockery and ridicule to those around us.

poem.verse: 14You make us a joke among the nations,

poetryblock.poem: a laughing-stock among the peoples.

poem.verse: 15My disgrace is before me all day long,

poetryblock.poem: and shame has covered my face,

poem.verse: 16because of the taunts of the scorner and reviler,

poetryblock.poem: because of the enemy and avenger.

poem.verse: 17All this has happened to us,

poetryblock.poem: but we have not forgotten you
or betrayed your covenant.

poem.verse: 18Our hearts have not turned back;

poetryblock.poem: our steps have not strayed from your path.

poem.verse: 19But you have crushed us in a haunt of jackals

poetryblock.poem: and have covered us with deepest darkness.

poem.verse: 20If we had forgotten the name of our God

poetryblock.poem: and spread out our hands to a foreign god,

poem.verse: 21wouldn’t God have found this out,

poetryblock.poem: since he knows the secrets of the heart?

poem.verse: 22Because of you we are being put to death all day long;

poetryblock.poem: we are counted as sheep to be slaughtered.

poem.verse: 23Wake up, Lord! Why are you sleeping?

poetryblock.poem: Get up! Don’t reject us for ever!

poem.verse: 24Why do you hide

poetryblock.poem: and forget our affliction and oppression?

poem.verse: 25For we have sunk down to the dust;

poetryblock.poem: our bodies cling to the ground.

poem.verse: 26Rise up! Help us!

poetryblock.poem: Redeem us because of your faithful love.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: according to ‘The Lilies.’ A 'Maskil' of the sons of Korah. A love song.

poem.verse: 1My heart is moved by a noble theme

poetryblock.poem: as I recite my verses to the king;
my tongue is the pen of a skilful writer.

poem.verse: 2You are the most handsome of men;

poetryblock.poem: grace flows from your lips.
Therefore God has blessed you for ever.

poem.verse: 3Mighty warrior, strap your sword at your side.

poetryblock.poem: In your majesty and splendour –

poem.verse: 4in your splendour ride triumphantly

poetryblock.poem: in the cause of truth, humility, and justice.
May your right hand show your awe-inspiring acts.

poem.verse: 5Your sharpened arrows pierce the hearts of the king’s enemies;

poetryblock.poem: the peoples fall under you.

poem.verse: 6Your throne, God, is for ever and ever;

poetryblock.poem: the sceptre of your kingdom is a sceptre of justice.

poem.verse: 7You love righteousness and hate wickedness;

poetryblock.poem: therefore God, your God, has anointed you with the oil of joy
more than your companions.

poem.verse: 8Myrrh, aloes, and cassia perfume all your garments;

poetryblock.poem: from ivory palaces harps bring you joy.

poem.verse: 9Kings’ daughters are among your honoured women;

poetryblock.poem: the queen, adorned with gold from Ophir,
stands at your right hand.

poem.verse: 10Listen, daughter, pay attention and consider:

poetryblock.poem: Forget your people and your father’s house,

poem.verse: 11and the king will desire your beauty.

poetryblock.poem: Bow down to him, for he is your lord.

poem.verse: 12The daughter of Tyre, the wealthy people,

poetryblock.poem: will seek your favour with gifts.

poem.verse: 13In her chamber, the royal daughter is all glorious,

poetryblock.poem: her clothing embroidered with gold.

poem.verse: 14In colourful garments she is led to the king;

poetryblock.poem: after her, the virgins, her companions, are brought to you.

poem.verse: 15They are led in with gladness and rejoicing;

poetryblock.poem: they enter the king’s palace.

poem.verse: 16Your sons will succeed your ancestors;

poetryblock.poem: you will make them princes throughout the land.

poem.verse: 17I will cause your name to be remembered for all generations;

poetryblock.poem: therefore the peoples will praise you for ever and ever.

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A song of the sons of Korah. According to 'Alamoth'.

poem.verse: 1God is our refuge and strength,

poetryblock.poem: a helper who is always found
in times of trouble.

poem.verse: 2Therefore we will not be afraid,

poetryblock.poem: though the earth trembles
and the mountains topple
into the depths of the seas,

poem.verse: 3though its water roars and foams

poetryblock.poem: and the mountains quake with its turmoil.'Selah'

poem.verse: 4There is a river –

poetryblock.poem: its streams delight the city of God,
the holy dwelling place of the Most High.

poem.verse: 5God is within her; she will not be toppled.

poetryblock.poem: God will help her when the morning dawns.

poem.verse: 6Nations rage, kingdoms topple;

poetryblock.poem: the earth melts when he lifts his voice.

poem.verse: 7The Lord of Armies is with us;

poetryblock.poem: the God of Jacob is our stronghold.'Selah'

poem.verse: 8Come, see the works of the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: who brings devastation on the earth.

poem.verse: 9He makes wars cease throughout the earth.

poetryblock.poem: He shatters bows and cuts spears to pieces;
he sets carts ablaze.

poem.verse: 10‘Stop fighting, and know that I am God,

poetryblock.poem: exalted among the nations, exalted on the earth.’

poem.verse: 11The Lord of Armies is with us;

poetryblock.poem: the God of Jacob is our stronghold.'Selah'

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A psalm of the sons of Korah.

poem.verse: 1Clap your hands, all you peoples;

poetryblock.poem: shout to God with a jubilant cry.

poem.verse: 2For the Lord, the Most High, is awe-inspiring,

poetryblock.poem: a great King over the whole earth.

poem.verse: 3He subdues peoples under us

poetryblock.poem: and nations under our feet.

poem.verse: 4He chooses for us our inheritance –

poetryblock.poem: the pride of Jacob, whom he loves.'Selah'

poem.verse: 5God ascends among shouts of joy,

poetryblock.poem: the Lord, with the sound of a ram’s horn.

poem.verse: 6Sing praise to God, sing praise;

poetryblock.poem: sing praise to our King, sing praise!

poem.verse: 7Sing a song of wisdom,

poetryblock.poem: for God is King of the whole earth.

poem.verse: 8God reigns over the nations;

poetryblock.poem: God is seated on his holy throne.

poem.verse: 9The nobles of the peoples have assembled

poetryblock.poem: with the people of the God of Abraham.
For the leaders of the earth belong to God;
he is greatly exalted.

chapter.head2: A song. A psalm of the sons of Korah.

poem.verse: 1The Lord is great and highly praised

poetryblock.poem: in the city of our God.
His holy mountain, 2rising splendidly,
is the joy of the whole earth.
Mount Zion ​– ​the summit of Zaphon ​– ​
is the city of the great King.

poem.verse: 3God is known as a stronghold

poetryblock.poem: in its citadels.

poem.verse: 4Look! The kings assembled;

poetryblock.poem: they advanced together.

poem.verse: 5They looked and froze with fear;

poetryblock.poem: they fled in terror.

poem.verse: 6Trembling seized them there,

poetryblock.poem: agony like that of a woman in labour,

poem.verse: 7as you wrecked the ships of Tarshish

poetryblock.poem: with the east wind.

poem.verse: 8Just as we heard, so we have seen

poetryblock.poem: in the city of the Lord of Armies,
in the city of our God;
God will establish it for ever.'Selah'

poem.verse: 9God, within your temple,

poetryblock.poem: we contemplate your faithful love.

poem.verse: 10Like your name, God, so your praise

poetryblock.poem: reaches to the ends of the earth;
your right hand is filled with justice.

poem.verse: 11Mount Zion is glad.

poetryblock.poem: Judah’s villages rejoice
because of your judgements.

poem.verse: 12Go round Zion, encircle it;

poetryblock.poem: count its towers,

poem.verse: 13note its ramparts; tour its citadels

poetryblock.poem: so that you can tell a future generation:

poem.verse: 14‘This God, our God for ever and ever –

poetryblock.poem: he will always lead us.’

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A psalm of the sons of Korah.

poem.verse: 1Hear this, all you peoples;

poetryblock.poem: listen, all who inhabit the world,

poem.verse: 2both low and high,

poetryblock.poem: rich and poor together.

poem.verse: 3My mouth speaks wisdom;

poetryblock.poem: my heart’s meditation brings understanding.

poem.verse: 4I turn my ear to a proverb;

poetryblock.poem: I explain my riddle with a lyre.

poem.verse: 5Why should I fear in times of trouble?

poetryblock.poem: The iniquity of my foes surrounds me.

poem.verse: 6They trust in their wealth

poetryblock.poem: and boast of their abundant riches.

poem.verse: 7Yet these cannot redeem a person

poetryblock.poem: or pay his ransom to God –

poem.verse: 8since the price of redeeming him is too costly,

poetryblock.poem: one should for ever stop trying –

poem.verse: 9so that he may live for ever

poetryblock.poem: and not see the Pit.

poem.verse: 10For one can see that the wise die;

poetryblock.poem: the foolish and stupid also pass away.
Then they leave their wealth to others.

poem.verse: 11Their graves are their permanent homes,

poetryblock.poem: their dwellings from generation to generation,
though they have named estates after themselves.

poem.verse: 12But despite his assets, mankind will not last;

poetryblock.poem: he is like the animals that perish.

poem.verse: 13This is the way of those who are arrogant,

poetryblock.poem: and of their followers,
who approve of their words.'Selah'

poem.verse: 14Like sheep they are headed for Sheol;

poetryblock.poem: Death will shepherd them.
The upright will rule over them in the morning,
and their form will waste away in Sheol,
far from their lofty abode.

poem.verse: 15But God will redeem me

poetryblock.poem: from the power of Sheol,
for he will take me.'Selah'

poem.verse: 16Do not be afraid when a person gets rich,

poetryblock.poem: when the wealth of his house increases.

poem.verse: 17For when he dies, he will take nothing at all;

poetryblock.poem: his wealth will not follow him down.

poem.verse: 18Though he blesses himself during his lifetime –

poetryblock.poem: and you are acclaimed when you do well for yourself –

poem.verse: 19he will go to the generation of his ancestors;

poetryblock.poem: they will never see the light.

poem.verse: 20Mankind, with his assets

poetryblock.poem: but without understanding,
is like the animals that perish.

chapter.head2: A psalm of Asaph.

poem.verse: 1The Mighty One, God, the Lord, speaks;

poetryblock.poem: he summons the earth
from the rising of the sun to its setting.

poem.verse: 2From Zion, the perfection of beauty,

poetryblock.poem: God appears in radiance.

poem.verse: 3Our God is coming; he will not be silent!

poetryblock.poem: Devouring fire precedes him,
and a storm rages around him.

poem.verse: 4On high, he summons heaven and earth

poetryblock.poem: in order to judge his people:

poem.verse: 5‘Gather my faithful ones to me,

poetryblock.poem: those who made a covenant with me by sacrifice.’

poem.verse: 6The heavens proclaim his righteousness,

poetryblock.poem: for God is the Judge.'Selah'

poem.verse: 7‘Listen, my people, and I will speak;

poetryblock.poem: I will testify against you, Israel.
I am God, your God.

poem.verse: 8I do not rebuke you for your sacrifices

poetryblock.poem: or for your burnt offerings,
which are continually before me.

poem.verse: 9I will not take a bull from your household

poetryblock.poem: or male goats from your pens,

poem.verse: 10for every animal of the forest is mine,

poetryblock.poem: the cattle on a thousand hills.

poem.verse: 11I know every bird of the mountains,

poetryblock.poem: and the creatures of the field are mine.

poem.verse: 12If I were hungry, I would not tell you,

poetryblock.poem: for the world and everything in it is mine.

poem.verse: 13Do I eat the flesh of bulls

poetryblock.poem: or drink the blood of goats?

poem.verse: 14Offer a thanksgiving sacrifice to God,

poetryblock.poem: and pay your vows to the Most High.

poem.verse: 15Call on me in a day of trouble;

poetryblock.poem: I will rescue you, and you will honour me.’

poem.verse: 16But God says to the wicked:

poetryblock.poem: ‘What right do you have to recite my statutes
and to take my covenant on your lips?

poem.verse: 17You hate instruction

poetryblock.poem: and fling my words behind you.

poem.verse: 18When you see a thief,

poetryblock.poem: you make friends with him,
and you associate with adulterers.

poem.verse: 19You unleash your mouth for evil

poetryblock.poem: and harness your tongue for deceit.

poem.verse: 20You sit, maligning your brother,

poetryblock.poem: slandering your mother’s son.

poem.verse: 21You have done these things, and I kept silent;

poetryblock.poem: you thought I was just like you.
But I will rebuke you
and lay out the case before you.

poem.verse: 22‘Understand this, you who forget God,

poetryblock.poem: or I will tear you apart,
and there will be no one to rescue you.

poem.verse: 23Whoever offers a thanksgiving sacrifice honours me,

poetryblock.poem: and whoever orders his conduct,
I will show him the salvation of God.’

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A psalm of David, when the prophet Nathan came to him after he had gone to Bathsheba.

poem.verse: 1Be gracious to me, God,

poetryblock.poem: according to your faithful love;
according to your abundant compassion,
blot out my rebellion.

poem.verse: 2Completely wash away my guilt

poetryblock.poem: and cleanse me from my sin.

poem.verse: 3For I am conscious of my rebellion,

poetryblock.poem: and my sin is always before me.

poem.verse: 4Against you ​– ​you alone ​– ​I have sinned

poetryblock.poem: and done this evil in your sight.
So you are right when you pass sentence;
you are blameless when you judge.

poem.verse: 5Indeed, I was guilty when I was born;

poetryblock.poem: I was sinful when my mother conceived me.

poem.verse: 6Surely you desire integrity in the inner self,

poetryblock.poem: and you teach me wisdom deep within.

poem.verse: 7Purify me with hyssop, and I will be clean;

poetryblock.poem: wash me, and I will be whiter than snow.

poem.verse: 8Let me hear joy and gladness;

poetryblock.poem: let the bones you have crushed rejoice.

poem.verse: 9Turn your face away from my sins

poetryblock.poem: and blot out all my guilt.

poem.verse: 10God, create a clean heart for me

poetryblock.poem: and renew a steadfast spirit within me.

poem.verse: 11Do not banish me from your presence

poetryblock.poem: or take your Holy Spirit from me.

poem.verse: 12Restore the joy of your salvation to me,

poetryblock.poem: and sustain me by giving me a willing spirit.

poem.verse: 13Then I will teach the rebellious your ways,

poetryblock.poem: and sinners will return to you.

poem.verse: 14Save me from the guilt of bloodshed, God –

poetryblock.poem: God of my salvation –
and my tongue will sing of your righteousness.

poem.verse: 15Lord, open my lips,

poetryblock.poem: and my mouth will declare your praise.

poem.verse: 16You do not want a sacrifice, or I would give it;

poetryblock.poem: you are not pleased with a burnt offering.

poem.verse: 17The sacrifice pleasing to God is a broken spirit.

poetryblock.poem: You will not despise a broken and humbled heart, God.

poem.verse: 18In your good pleasure, cause Zion to prosper;

poetryblock.poem: build the walls of Jerusalem.

poem.verse: 19Then you will delight in righteous sacrifices,

poetryblock.poem: whole burnt offerings;
then bulls will be offered on your altar.

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A 'Maskil' of David. When Doeg the Edomite went and reported to Saul, telling him, ‘David went to Ahimelech’s house.’

poem.verse: 1Why boast about evil, you hero!

poetryblock.poem: God’s faithful love is constant.

poem.verse: 2Like a sharpened razor,

poetryblock.poem: your tongue devises destruction,
working treachery.

poem.verse: 3You love evil instead of good,

poetryblock.poem: lying instead of speaking truthfully.'Selah'

poem.verse: 4You love any words that destroy,

poetryblock.poem: you treacherous tongue!

poem.verse: 5This is why God will bring you down for ever.

poetryblock.poem: He will take you, ripping you out of your tent;
he will uproot you from the land of the living.'Selah'

poem.verse: 6The righteous will see and fear,

poetryblock.poem: and they will derisively say about that hero,

poem.verse: 7‘Here is the man

poetryblock.poem: who would not make God his refuge,
but trusted in the abundance of his riches,
taking refuge in his destructive behaviour.’

poem.verse: 8But I am like a flourishing olive tree

poetryblock.poem: in the house of God;
I trust in God’s faithful love for ever and ever.

poem.verse: 9I will praise you for ever for what you have done.

poetryblock.poem: In the presence of your faithful people,
I will put my hope in your name, for it is good.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: on 'Mahalath'. A 'Maskil' of David.

poem.verse: 1The fool says in his heart, ‘There’s no God.’

poetryblock.poem: They are corrupt, and they do vile deeds.
There is no one who does good.

poem.verse: 2God looks down from heaven on the human race

poetryblock.poem: to see if there is one who is wise,
one who seeks God.

poem.verse: 3All have turned away;

poetryblock.poem: all alike have become corrupt.
There is no one who does good,
not even one.

poem.verse: 4Will evildoers never understand?

poetryblock.poem: They consume my people as they consume bread;
they do not call on God.

poem.verse: 5Then they will be filled with dread –

poetryblock.poem: dread like no other –
because God will scatter
the bones of those who besiege you.
You will put them to shame,
for God has rejected them.

poem.verse: 6Oh, that Israel’s deliverance would come from Zion!

poetryblock.poem: When God restores the fortunes of his people,
let Jacob rejoice, let Israel be glad.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: with stringed instruments. A 'Maskil' of David. When the Ziphites went and said to Saul, ‘Is David not hiding among us? ’

poem.verse: 1God, save me by your name,

poetryblock.poem: and vindicate me by your might!

poem.verse: 2God, hear my prayer;

poetryblock.poem: listen to the words from my mouth.

poem.verse: 3For strangers rise up against me,

poetryblock.poem: and violent men intend to kill me.
They do not let God guide them.'Selah'

poem.verse: 4God is my helper;

poetryblock.poem: the Lord is the sustainer of my life.

poem.verse: 5He will repay my adversaries for their evil.

poetryblock.poem: Because of your faithfulness, annihilate them.

poem.verse: 6I will sacrifice a freewill offering to you.

poetryblock.poem: I will praise your name, Lord,
because it is good.

poem.verse: 7For he has rescued me from every trouble,

poetryblock.poem: and my eye has looked down on my enemies.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: with stringed instruments. A 'Maskil' of David.

poem.verse: 1God, listen to my prayer

poetryblock.poem: and do not hide from my plea for help.

poem.verse: 2Pay attention to me and answer me.

poetryblock.poem: I am restless and in turmoil with my complaint,

poem.verse: 3because of the enemy’s words,

poetryblock.poem: because of the pressure of the wicked.
For they bring down disaster on me
and harass me in anger.

poem.verse: 4My heart shudders within me;

poetryblock.poem: terrors of death sweep over me.

poem.verse: 5Fear and trembling grip me;

poetryblock.poem: horror has overwhelmed me.

poem.verse: 6I said, ‘If only I had wings like a dove!

poetryblock.poem: I would fly away and find rest.

poem.verse: 7How far away I would flee;

poetryblock.poem: I would stay in the wilderness.'Selah'

poem.verse: 8I would hurry to my shelter

poetryblock.poem: from the raging wind and the storm.’

poem.verse: 9Lord, confuse and confound their speech,

poetryblock.poem: for I see violence and strife in the city;

poem.verse: 10day and night they make the rounds on its walls.

poetryblock.poem: Crime and trouble are within it;

poem.verse: 11destruction is inside it;

poetryblock.poem: oppression and deceit never leave its marketplace.

poem.verse: 12Now it is not an enemy who insults me –

poetryblock.poem: otherwise I could bear it;
it is not a foe who rises up against me –
otherwise I could hide from him.

poem.verse: 13But it is you, a man who is my peer,

poetryblock.poem: my companion and good friend!

poem.verse: 14We used to have close fellowship;

poetryblock.poem: we walked with the crowd into the house of God.

poem.verse: 15Let death take them by surprise;

poetryblock.poem: let them go down to Sheol alive,
because evil is in their homes and within them.

poem.verse: 16But I call to God,

poetryblock.poem: and the Lord will save me.

poem.verse: 17I complain and groan morning, noon, and night,

poetryblock.poem: and he hears my voice.

poem.verse: 18Though many are against me,

poetryblock.poem: he will redeem me from my battle unharmed.

poem.verse: 19God, the one enthroned from long ago,

poetryblock.poem: will hear and will humiliate them'Selah'
because they do not change
and do not fear God.

poem.verse: 20My friend acts violently

poetryblock.poem: against those at peace with him;
he violates his covenant.

poem.verse: 21His buttery words are smooth,

poetryblock.poem: but war is in his heart.
His words are softer than oil,
but they are drawn swords.

poem.verse: 22Cast your burden on the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and he will sustain you;
he will never allow the righteous to be shaken.

poem.verse: 23God, you will bring them down

poetryblock.poem: to the Pit of destruction;
men of bloodshed and treachery
will not live out half their days.
But I will trust in you.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: according to ‘A Silent Dove Far Away.’ A 'Miktam' of David. When the Philistines seized him in Gath.

poem.verse: 1Be gracious to me, God, for a man is trampling me;

poetryblock.poem: he fights and oppresses me all day long.

poem.verse: 2My adversaries trample me all day,

poetryblock.poem: for many arrogantly fight against me.

poem.verse: 3When I am afraid,

poetryblock.poem: I will trust in you.

poem.verse: 4In God, whose word I praise,

poetryblock.poem: in God I trust; I will not be afraid.
What can mere mortals do to me?

poem.verse: 5They twist my words all day long;

poetryblock.poem: all their thoughts against me are evil.

poem.verse: 6They stir up strife, they lurk,

poetryblock.poem: they watch my steps
while they wait to take my life.

poem.verse: 7Will they escape in spite of such sin?

poetryblock.poem: God, bring down the nations in wrath.

poem.verse: 8You yourself have recorded my wanderings.

poetryblock.poem: Put my tears in your bottle.
Are they not in your book?

poem.verse: 9Then my enemies will retreat on the day when I call.

poetryblock.poem: This I know: God is for me.

poem.verse: 10In God, whose word I praise,

poetryblock.poem: in the Lord, whose word I praise,

poem.verse: 11in God I trust; I will not be afraid.

poetryblock.poem: What can mere humans do to me?

poem.verse: 12I am bound by vows to you, God;

poetryblock.poem: I will make my thanksgiving sacrifices to you.

poem.verse: 13For you rescued me from death,

poetryblock.poem: even my feet from stumbling,
to walk before God in the light of life.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: ‘Do Not Destroy.’ A 'Miktam' of David. When he fled before Saul into the cave.

poem.verse: 1Be gracious to me, God, be gracious to me,

poetryblock.poem: for I take refuge in you.
I will seek refuge in the shadow of your wings
until danger passes.

poem.verse: 2I call to God Most High,

poetryblock.poem: to God who fulfils his purpose for me.

poem.verse: 3He reaches down from heaven and saves me,

poetryblock.poem: challenging the one who tramples me.'Selah'
God sends his faithful love and truth.

poem.verse: 4I am surrounded by lions;

poetryblock.poem: I lie down among devouring lions –
people whose teeth are spears and arrows,
whose tongues are sharp swords.

poem.verse: 5God, be exalted above the heavens;

poetryblock.poem: let your glory be over the whole earth.

poem.verse: 6They prepared a net for my steps;

poetryblock.poem: I was despondent.
They dug a pit ahead of me,
but they fell into it!'Selah'

poem.verse: 7My heart is confident, God, my heart is confident.

poetryblock.poem: I will sing; I will sing praises.

poem.verse: 8Wake up, my soul!

poetryblock.poem: Wake up, harp and lyre!
I will wake up the dawn.

poem.verse: 9I will praise you, Lord, among the peoples;

poetryblock.poem: I will sing praises to you among the nations.

poem.verse: 10For your faithful love is as high as the heavens;

poetryblock.poem: your faithfulness reaches the clouds.

poem.verse: 11God, be exalted above the heavens;

poetryblock.poem: let your glory be over the whole earth.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: ‘Do Not Destroy.’ A 'Miktam' of David.

poem.verse: 1Do you really speak righteously, you mighty ones?

poetryblock.poem: Do you judge people fairly?

poem.verse: 2No, you practise injustice in your hearts;

poetryblock.poem: with your hands you weigh out violence in the land.

poem.verse: 3The wicked go astray from the womb;

poetryblock.poem: liars wander about from birth.

poem.verse: 4They have venom like the venom of a snake,

poetryblock.poem: like the deaf cobra that stops up its ears,

poem.verse: 5that does not listen to the sound of the charmers

poetryblock.poem: who skilfully weave spells.

poem.verse: 6God, knock the teeth out of their mouths;

poetryblock.poem: Lord, tear out the young lions’ fangs.

poem.verse: 7May they vanish like water that flows by;

poetryblock.poem: may they aim their blunted arrows.

poem.verse: 8Like a slug that moves along in slime,

poetryblock.poem: like a woman’s miscarried child,
may they not see the sun.

poem.verse: 9Before your pots can feel the heat of the thorns –

poetryblock.poem: whether green or burning –
he will sweep them away.

poem.verse: 10The righteous one will rejoice

poetryblock.poem: when he sees the retribution;
he will wash his feet in the blood of the wicked.

poem.verse: 11Then people will say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Yes, there is a reward for the righteous!
There is a God who judges on earth! ’

chapter.head2: For the choir director: ‘Do Not Destroy.’ A 'Miktam' of David. When Saul sent agents to watch the house and kill him.

poem.verse: 1Rescue me from my enemies, my God;

poetryblock.poem: protect me from those who rise up against me.

poem.verse: 2Rescue me from evildoers,

poetryblock.poem: and save me from men of bloodshed.

poem.verse: 3Because look, Lord, they set an ambush for me.

poetryblock.poem: Powerful men attack me,
but not because of any sin or rebellion of mine.

poem.verse: 4For no fault of mine,

poetryblock.poem: they run and take up a position.
Awake to help me, and take notice.

poem.verse: 5Lord God of Armies, you are the God of Israel.

poetryblock.poem: Rise up to punish all the nations;
do not show favour to any wicked traitors.'Selah'

poem.verse: 6They return at evening, snarling like dogs

poetryblock.poem: and prowling round the city.

poem.verse: 7Look, they spew from their mouths –

poetryblock.poem: sharp words from their lips.
‘For who,’ they say, ‘will hear? ’

poem.verse: 8But you laugh at them, Lord;

poetryblock.poem: you ridicule all the nations.

poem.verse: 9I will keep watch for you, my strength,

poetryblock.poem: because God is my stronghold.

poem.verse: 10My faithful God will come to meet me;

poetryblock.poem: God will let me look down on my adversaries.

poem.verse: 11Do not kill them; otherwise, my people will forget.

poetryblock.poem: By your power, make them homeless wanderers
and bring them down,
Lord, our shield.

poem.verse: 12For the sin of their mouths and the words of their lips,

poetryblock.poem: let them be caught in their pride.
They utter curses and lies.

poem.verse: 13Consume them in fury;

poetryblock.poem: consume them until they are gone.
Then people will know throughout the earth
that God rules over Jacob.'Selah'

poem.verse: 14And they return at evening, snarling like dogs

poetryblock.poem: and prowling round the city.

poem.verse: 15They scavenge for food;

poetryblock.poem: they growl if they are not satisfied.

poem.verse: 16But I will sing of your strength

poetryblock.poem: and will joyfully proclaim
your faithful love in the morning.
For you have been a stronghold for me,
a refuge in my day of trouble.

poem.verse: 17To you, my strength, I sing praises,

poetryblock.poem: because God is my stronghold –
my faithful God.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: according to ‘The Lily of Testimony.’ A 'Miktam' of David for teaching. When he fought with Aram-naharaim and Aram-zobah, and Joab returned and struck Edom in Salt Valley, killing twelve thousand.

poem.verse: 1God, you have rejected us;

poetryblock.poem: you have broken us down;
you have been angry. Restore us!

poem.verse: 2You have shaken the land and split it open.

poetryblock.poem: Heal its fissures, for it shudders.

poem.verse: 3You have made your people suffer hardship;

poetryblock.poem: you have given us wine to drink
that made us stagger.

poem.verse: 4You have given a signal flag to those who fear you,

poetryblock.poem: so that they can flee before the archers.'Selah'

poem.verse: 5Save with your right hand, and answer me,

poetryblock.poem: so that those you love may be rescued.

poem.verse: 6God has spoken in his sanctuary:

poetryblock.poem: ‘I will celebrate!
I will divide up Shechem.
I will apportion the Valley of Succoth.

poem.verse: 7Gilead is mine, Manasseh is mine,

poetryblock.poem: and Ephraim is my helmet;
Judah is my sceptre.

poem.verse: 8Moab is my washbasin.

poetryblock.poem: I throw my sandal on Edom;
I shout in triumph over Philistia.’

poem.verse: 9Who will bring me to the fortified city?

poetryblock.poem: Who will lead me to Edom?

poem.verse: 10God, haven’t you rejected us?

poetryblock.poem: God, you do not march out with our armies.

poem.verse: 11Give us aid against the foe,

poetryblock.poem: for human help is worthless.

poem.verse: 12With God we will perform valiantly;

poetryblock.poem: he will trample our foes.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: on stringed instruments. Of David.

poem.verse: 1God, hear my cry;

poetryblock.poem: pay attention to my prayer.

poem.verse: 2I call to you from the ends of the earth

poetryblock.poem: when my heart is without strength.
Lead me to a rock that is high above me,

poem.verse: 3for you have been a refuge for me,

poetryblock.poem: a strong tower in the face of the enemy.

poem.verse: 4I will dwell in your tent for ever

poetryblock.poem: and take refuge under the shelter of your wings.'Selah'

poem.verse: 5God, you have heard my vows;

poetryblock.poem: you have given a heritage
to those who fear your name.

poem.verse: 6Add days to the king’s life;

poetryblock.poem: may his years span many generations.

poem.verse: 7May he sit enthroned before God for ever.

poetryblock.poem: Appoint faithful love and truth to guard him.

poem.verse: 8Then I will continually sing of your name,

poetryblock.poem: fulfilling my vows day by day.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: according to Jeduthun. A psalm of David.

poem.verse: 1I am at rest in God alone;

poetryblock.poem: my salvation comes from him.

poem.verse: 2He alone is my rock and my salvation,

poetryblock.poem: my stronghold; I will never be shaken.

poem.verse: 3How long will you threaten a man?

poetryblock.poem: Will all of you attack
as if he were a leaning wall
or a tottering fence?

poem.verse: 4They only plan to bring him down

poetryblock.poem: from his high position.
They take pleasure in lying;
they bless with their mouths,
but they curse inwardly.'Selah'

poem.verse: 5Rest in God alone, my soul,

poetryblock.poem: for my hope comes from him.

poem.verse: 6He alone is my rock and my salvation,

poetryblock.poem: my stronghold; I will not be shaken.

poem.verse: 7My salvation and glory depend on God, my strong rock.

poetryblock.poem: My refuge is in God.

poem.verse: 8Trust in him at all times, you people;

poetryblock.poem: pour out your hearts before him.
God is our refuge.'Selah'

poem.verse: 9Common people are only a vapour;

poetryblock.poem: important people, an illusion.
Together on a scale,
they weigh less than a vapour.

poem.verse: 10Place no trust in oppression

poetryblock.poem: or false hope in robbery.
If wealth increases,
don’t set your heart on it.

poem.verse: 11God has spoken once;

poetryblock.poem: I have heard this twice:
strength belongs to God,

poem.verse: 12and faithful love belongs to you, Lord.

poetryblock.poem: For you repay each according to his works.

chapter.head2: A psalm of David. When he was in the Wilderness of Judah.

poem.verse: 1God, you are my God; I eagerly seek you.

poetryblock.poem: I thirst for you;
my body faints for you
in a land that is dry, desolate, and without water.

poem.verse: 2So I gaze on you in the sanctuary

poetryblock.poem: to see your strength and your glory.

poem.verse: 3My lips will glorify you

poetryblock.poem: because your faithful love is better than life.

poem.verse: 4So I will bless you as long as I live;

poetryblock.poem: at your name, I will lift up my hands.

poem.verse: 5You satisfy me as with rich food;

poetryblock.poem: my mouth will praise you with joyful lips.

poem.verse: 6When I think of you as I lie on my bed,

poetryblock.poem: I meditate on you during the night watches

poem.verse: 7because you are my helper;

poetryblock.poem: I will rejoice in the shadow of your wings.

poem.verse: 8I follow close to you;

poetryblock.poem: your right hand holds on to me.

poem.verse: 9But those who intend to destroy my life

poetryblock.poem: will go into the depths of the earth.

poem.verse: 10They will be given over to the power of the sword;

poetryblock.poem: they will become a meal for jackals.

poem.verse: 11But the king will rejoice in God;

poetryblock.poem: all who swear by him will boast,
for the mouths of liars will be shut.

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A psalm of David.

poem.verse: 1God, hear my voice when I am in anguish.

poetryblock.poem: Protect my life from the terror of the enemy.

poem.verse: 2Hide me from the scheming of wicked people,

poetryblock.poem: from the mob of evildoers,

poem.verse: 3who sharpen their tongues like swords

poetryblock.poem: and aim bitter words like arrows,

poem.verse: 4shooting from concealed places at the blameless.

poetryblock.poem: They shoot at him suddenly and are not afraid.

poem.verse: 5They adopt an evil plan;

poetryblock.poem: they talk about hiding traps and say,
‘Who will see them? ’

poem.verse: 6They devise crimes and say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘We have perfected a secret plan.’
The inner man and the heart are mysterious.

poem.verse: 7But God will shoot them with arrows;

poetryblock.poem: suddenly, they will be wounded.

poem.verse: 8They will be made to stumble;

poetryblock.poem: their own tongues work against them.
All who see them will shake their heads.

poem.verse: 9Then everyone will fear

poetryblock.poem: and will tell about God’s work,
for they will understand what he has done.

poem.verse: 10The righteous one rejoices in the Lord

poetryblock.poem: and takes refuge in him;
all those who are upright in heart
will offer praise.

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A psalm of David. A song.

poem.verse: 1Praise is rightfully yours,

poetryblock.poem: God, in Zion;
vows to you will be fulfilled.

poem.verse: 2All humanity will come to you,

poetryblock.poem: the one who hears prayer.

poem.verse: 3Iniquities overwhelm me;

poetryblock.poem: only you can atone for our rebellions.

poem.verse: 4How happy is the one you choose

poetryblock.poem: and bring near to live in your courts!
We will be satisfied with the goodness of your house,
the holiness of your temple.

poem.verse: 5You answer us in righteousness,

poetryblock.poem: with awe-inspiring works,
God of our salvation,
the hope of all the ends of the earth
and of the distant seas.

poem.verse: 6You establish the mountains by your power;

poetryblock.poem: you are robed with strength.

poem.verse: 7You silence the roar of the seas,

poetryblock.poem: the roar of their waves,
and the tumult of the nations.

poem.verse: 8Those who live far away are awed by your signs;

poetryblock.poem: you make east and west shout for joy.

poem.verse: 9You visit the earth and water it abundantly,

poetryblock.poem: enriching it greatly.
God’s stream is filled with water,
for you prepare the earth in this way,
providing people with corn.

poem.verse: 10You soften it with showers and bless its growth,

poetryblock.poem: soaking its furrows and levelling its ridges.

poem.verse: 11You crown the year with your goodness;

poetryblock.poem: your carts overflow with plenty.

poem.verse: 12The wilderness pastures overflow,

poetryblock.poem: and the hills are robed with joy.

poem.verse: 13The pastures are clothed with flocks

poetryblock.poem: and the valleys covered with corn.
They shout in triumph; indeed, they sing.

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A song. A psalm.

poem.verse: 1Let the whole earth shout joyfully to God!
2Sing about the glory of his name;

poetryblock.poem: make his praise glorious.

poem.verse: 3Say to God, ‘How awe-inspiring are your works!

poetryblock.poem: Your enemies will cringe before you
because of your great strength.

poem.verse: 4The whole earth will worship you

poetryblock.poem: and sing praise to you.
They will sing praise to your name.’'Selah'

poem.verse: 5Come and see the wonders of God;

poetryblock.poem: his acts for humanity are awe-inspiring.

poem.verse: 6He turned the sea into dry land,

poetryblock.poem: and they crossed the river on foot.
There we rejoiced in him.

poem.verse: 7He rules for ever by his might;

poetryblock.poem: he keeps his eye on the nations.
The rebellious should not exalt themselves.'Selah'

poem.verse: 8Bless our God, you peoples;

poetryblock.poem: let the sound of his praise be heard.

poem.verse: 9He keeps us alive

poetryblock.poem: and does not allow our feet to slip.

poem.verse: 10For you, God, tested us;

poetryblock.poem: you refined us as silver is refined.

poem.verse: 11You lured us into a trap;

poetryblock.poem: you placed burdens on our backs.

poem.verse: 12You let men ride over our heads;

poetryblock.poem: we went through fire and water,
but you brought us out to abundance.

poem.verse: 13I will enter your house with burnt offerings;

poetryblock.poem: I will pay you my vows

poem.verse: 14that my lips promised

poetryblock.poem: and my mouth spoke during my distress.

poem.verse: 15I will offer you fattened sheep as burnt offerings,

poetryblock.poem: with the fragrant smoke of rams;
I will sacrifice bulls with goats.'Selah'

poem.verse: 16Come and listen, all who fear God,

poetryblock.poem: and I will tell what he has done for me.

poem.verse: 17I cried out to him with my mouth,

poetryblock.poem: and praise was on my tongue.

poem.verse: 18If I had been aware of malice in my heart,

poetryblock.poem: the Lord would not have listened.

poem.verse: 19However, God has listened;

poetryblock.poem: he has paid attention to the sound of my prayer.

poem.verse: 20Blessed be God!

poetryblock.poem: He has not turned away my prayer
or turned his faithful love from me.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: with stringed instruments. A psalm. A song.

poem.verse: 1May God be gracious to us and bless us;

poetryblock.poem: may he make his face shine upon us'Selah'

poem.verse: 2so that your way may be known on earth,

poetryblock.poem: your salvation among all nations.

poem.verse: 3Let the peoples praise you, God;

poetryblock.poem: let all the peoples praise you.

poem.verse: 4Let the nations rejoice and shout for joy,

poetryblock.poem: for you judge the peoples with fairness
and lead the nations on earth.'Selah'

poem.verse: 5Let the peoples praise you, God,

poetryblock.poem: let all the peoples praise you.

poem.verse: 6The earth has produced its harvest;

poetryblock.poem: God, our God, blesses us.

poem.verse: 7God will bless us,

poetryblock.poem: and all the ends of the earth will fear him.

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A psalm of David. A song.

poem.verse: 1God arises. His enemies scatter,

poetryblock.poem: and those who hate him flee from his presence.

poem.verse: 2As smoke is blown away,

poetryblock.poem: so you blow them away.
As wax melts before the fire,
so the wicked are destroyed before God.

poem.verse: 3But the righteous are glad;

poetryblock.poem: they rejoice before God and celebrate with joy.

poem.verse: 4Sing to God! Sing praises to his name.

poetryblock.poem: Exalt him who rides on the clouds ​– ​
his name is the Lord ​– ​and celebrate before him.

poem.verse: 5God in his holy dwelling is

poetryblock.poem: a father of the fatherless
and a champion of widows.

poem.verse: 6God provides homes for those who are deserted.

poetryblock.poem: He leads out the prisoners to prosperity,
but the rebellious live in a scorched land.

poem.verse: 7God, when you went out before your people,

poetryblock.poem: when you marched through the desert,'Selah'

poem.verse: 8the earth trembled and the skies poured rain

poetryblock.poem: before God, the God of Sinai,
before God, the God of Israel.

poem.verse: 9You, God, showered abundant rain;

poetryblock.poem: you revived your inheritance when it languished.

poem.verse: 10Your people settled in it;

poetryblock.poem: God, you provided for the poor by your goodness.

poem.verse: 11The Lord gave the command;

poetryblock.poem: a great company of women brought the good news:

poem.verse: 12‘The kings of the armies flee ​– ​they flee! ’

poetryblock.poem: She who stays at home divides the spoil.

poem.verse: 13While you lie among the sheepfolds,

poetryblock.poem: the wings of a dove are covered with silver,
and its feathers with glistening gold.

poem.verse: 14When the Almighty scattered kings in the land,

poetryblock.poem: it snowed on Zalmon.

poem.verse: 15Mount Bashan is God’s towering mountain;

poetryblock.poem: Mount Bashan is a mountain of many peaks.

poem.verse: 16Why gaze with envy, you mountain peaks,

poetryblock.poem: at the mountain God desired for his abode?
The Lord will dwell there for ever!

poem.verse: 17God’s chariots are tens of thousands,

poetryblock.poem: thousands and thousands;
the Lord is among them in the sanctuary
as he was at Sinai.

poem.verse: 18You ascended to the heights, taking away captives;

poetryblock.poem: you received gifts from people,
even from the rebellious,
so that the Lord God might dwell there.

poem.verse: 19Blessed be the Lord!

poetryblock.poem: Day after day he bears our burdens;
God is our salvation.'Selah'

poem.verse: 20Our God is a God of salvation,

poetryblock.poem: and escape from death belongs to the Lord my Lord.

poem.verse: 21Surely God crushes the heads of his enemies,

poetryblock.poem: the hairy brow of one who goes on in his guilty acts.

poem.verse: 22The Lord said, ‘I will bring them back from Bashan;

poetryblock.poem: I will bring them back from the depths of the sea

poem.verse: 23so that your feet may wade in blood

poetryblock.poem: and your dogs’ tongues may have their share
from the enemies.’

poem.verse: 24People have seen your procession, God,

poetryblock.poem: the procession of my God,
my King, in the sanctuary.

poem.verse: 25Singers lead the way,

poetryblock.poem: with musicians following;
among them are young women
playing tambourines.

poem.verse: 26Bless God in the assemblies;

poetryblock.poem: bless the Lord from the fountain of Israel.

poem.verse: 27There is Benjamin, the youngest, leading them,

poetryblock.poem: the rulers of Judah in their assembly,
the rulers of Zebulun, the rulers of Naphtali.

poem.verse: 28Your God has decreed your strength.

poetryblock.poem: Show your strength, God,
you who have acted on our behalf.

poem.verse: 29Because of your temple at Jerusalem,

poetryblock.poem: kings will bring tribute to you.

poem.verse: 30Rebuke the beast in the reeds,

poetryblock.poem: the herd of bulls with the calves of the peoples.
Trample underfoot those with bars of silver.
Scatter the peoples who take pleasure in war.

poem.verse: 31Ambassadors will come from Egypt;

poetryblock.poem: Cush will stretch out its hands to God.

poem.verse: 32Sing to God, you kingdoms of the earth;

poetryblock.poem: sing praise to the Lord,'Selah'

poem.verse: 33to him who rides in the ancient, highest heavens.

poetryblock.poem: Look, he thunders with his powerful voice!

poem.verse: 34Ascribe power to God.

poetryblock.poem: His majesty is over Israel;
his power is among the clouds.

poem.verse: 35God, you are awe-inspiring in your sanctuaries.

poetryblock.poem: The God of Israel gives power and strength to his people.
Blessed be God!

chapter.head2: For the choir director: according to ‘The Lilies.’ Of David.

poem.verse: 1Save me, God,

poetryblock.poem: for the water has risen to my neck.

poem.verse: 2I have sunk in deep mud, and there is no foothold;

poetryblock.poem: I have come into deep water,
and a flood sweeps over me.

poem.verse: 3I am weary from my crying;

poetryblock.poem: my throat is parched.
My eyes fail, looking for my God.

poem.verse: 4Those who hate me without cause

poetryblock.poem: are more numerous than the hairs of my head;
my deceitful enemies, who would destroy me,
are powerful.
Though I did not steal, I must repay.

poem.verse: 5God, you know my foolishness,

poetryblock.poem: and my guilty acts are not hidden from you.

poem.verse: 6Do not let those who put their hope in you

poetryblock.poem: be disgraced because of me,
Lord God of Armies;
do not let those who seek you
be humiliated because of me,
God of Israel.

poem.verse: 7For I have endured insults because of you,

poetryblock.poem: and shame has covered my face.

poem.verse: 8I have become a stranger to my brothers

poetryblock.poem: and a foreigner to my mother’s sons

poem.verse: 9because zeal for your house has consumed me,

poetryblock.poem: and the insults of those who insult you
have fallen on me.

poem.verse: 10I mourned and fasted,

poetryblock.poem: but it brought me insults.

poem.verse: 11I wore sackcloth as my clothing,

poetryblock.poem: and I was a joke to them.

poem.verse: 12Those who sit at the city gate talk about me,

poetryblock.poem: and drunkards make up songs about me.

poem.verse: 13But as for me, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: my prayer to you is for a time of favour.
In your abundant, faithful love, God,
answer me with your sure salvation.

poem.verse: 14Rescue me from the miry mud; don’t let me sink.

poetryblock.poem: Let me be rescued from those who hate me
and from the deep water.

poem.verse: 15Don’t let the floodwaters sweep over me

poetryblock.poem: or the deep swallow me up;
don’t let the Pit close its mouth over me.

poem.verse: 16Answer me, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: for your faithful love is good.
In keeping with your abundant compassion,
turn to me.

poem.verse: 17Don’t hide your face from your servant,

poetryblock.poem: for I am in distress.
Answer me quickly!

poem.verse: 18Come near to me and redeem me;

poetryblock.poem: ransom me because of my enemies.

poem.verse: 19You know the insults I endure –

poetryblock.poem: my shame and disgrace.
You are aware of all my adversaries.

poem.verse: 20Insults have broken my heart,

poetryblock.poem: and I am in despair.
I waited for sympathy,
but there was none;
for comforters, but found no one.

poem.verse: 21Instead, they gave me gall for my food,

poetryblock.poem: and for my thirst
they gave me vinegar to drink.

poem.verse: 22Let their table set before them be a snare,

poetryblock.poem: and let it be a trap for their allies.

poem.verse: 23Let their eyes grow too dim to see,

poetryblock.poem: and let their hips continually quake.

poem.verse: 24Pour out your rage on them,

poetryblock.poem: and let your burning anger overtake them.

poem.verse: 25Make their fortification desolate;

poetryblock.poem: may no one live in their tents.

poem.verse: 26For they persecute the one you struck

poetryblock.poem: and talk about the pain of those you wounded.

poem.verse: 27Charge them with crime on top of crime;

poetryblock.poem: do not let them share in your righteousness.

poem.verse: 28Let them be erased from the book of life

poetryblock.poem: and not be recorded with the righteous.

poem.verse: 29But as for me ​– ​poor and in pain –

poetryblock.poem: let your salvation protect me, God.

poem.verse: 30I will praise God’s name with song

poetryblock.poem: and exalt him with thanksgiving.

poem.verse: 31That will please the Lord more than an ox,

poetryblock.poem: more than a bull with horns and hooves.

poem.verse: 32The humble will see it and rejoice.

poetryblock.poem: You who seek God, take heart!

poem.verse: 33For the Lord listens to the needy

poetryblock.poem: and does not despise
his own who are prisoners.

poem.verse: 34Let heaven and earth praise him,

poetryblock.poem: the seas and everything that moves in them,

poem.verse: 35for God will save Zion

poetryblock.poem: and build up the cities of Judah.
They will live there and possess it.

poem.verse: 36The descendants of his servants will inherit it,

poetryblock.poem: and those who love his name will live in it.

chapter.head2: For the choir director. Of David. To bring remembrance.

poem.verse: 1God, hurry to rescue me.

poetryblock.poem: Lord, hurry to help me!

poem.verse: 2Let those who seek to kill me

poetryblock.poem: be disgraced and confounded;
let those who wish me harm
be turned back and humiliated.

poem.verse: 3Let those who say, ‘Aha, aha! ’

poetryblock.poem: retreat because of their shame.

poem.verse: 4Let all who seek you rejoice and be glad in you;

poetryblock.poem: let those who love your salvation
continually say, ‘God is great! ’

poem.verse: 5I am oppressed and needy;

poetryblock.poem: hurry to me, God.
You are my help and my deliverer;
Lord, do not delay.

poem.verse: 1Lord, I seek refuge in you;

poetryblock.poem: let me never be disgraced.

poem.verse: 2In your justice, rescue and deliver me;

poetryblock.poem: listen closely to me and save me.

poem.verse: 3Be a rock of refuge for me,

poetryblock.poem: where I can always go.
Give the command to save me,
for you are my rock and fortress.

poem.verse: 4Deliver me, my God, from the power of the wicked,

poetryblock.poem: from the grasp of the unjust and oppressive.

poem.verse: 5For you are my hope, Lord God,

poetryblock.poem: my confidence from my youth.

poem.verse: 6I have leaned on you from birth;

poetryblock.poem: you took me from my mother’s womb.
My praise is always about you.

poem.verse: 7I am like a miraculous sign to many,

poetryblock.poem: and you are my strong refuge.

poem.verse: 8My mouth is full of praise

poetryblock.poem: and honour to you all day long.

poem.verse: 9Don’t discard me in my old age.

poetryblock.poem: As my strength fails, do not abandon me.

poem.verse: 10For my enemies talk about me,

poetryblock.poem: and those who spy on me plot together,

poem.verse: 11saying, ‘God has abandoned him;

poetryblock.poem: chase him and catch him,
for there is no one to rescue him.’

poem.verse: 12God, do not be far from me;

poetryblock.poem: my God, hurry to help me.

poem.verse: 13May my adversaries be disgraced and destroyed;

poetryblock.poem: may those who intend to harm me
be covered with disgrace and humiliation.

poem.verse: 14But I will hope continually

poetryblock.poem: and will praise you more and more.

poem.verse: 15My mouth will tell about your righteousness

poetryblock.poem: and your salvation all day long,
though I cannot sum them up.

poem.verse: 16I come because of the mighty acts of the Lord God;

poetryblock.poem: I will proclaim your righteousness, yours alone.

poem.verse: 17God, you have taught me from my youth,

poetryblock.poem: and I still proclaim your wondrous works.

poem.verse: 18Even while I am old and grey,

poetryblock.poem: God, do not abandon me,
while I proclaim your power
to another generation,
your strength to all who are to come.

poem.verse: 19Your righteousness reaches the heights, God,

poetryblock.poem: you who have done great things;
God, who is like you?

poem.verse: 20You caused me to experience

poetryblock.poem: many troubles and misfortunes,
but you will revive me again.
You will bring me up again,
even from the depths of the earth.

poem.verse: 21You will increase my honour

poetryblock.poem: and comfort me once again.

poem.verse: 22Therefore, I will praise you with a harp

poetryblock.poem: for your faithfulness, my God;
I will sing to you with a lyre,
Holy One of Israel.

poem.verse: 23My lips will shout for joy

poetryblock.poem: when I sing praise to you
because you have redeemed me.

poem.verse: 24Therefore, my tongue will proclaim

poetryblock.poem: your righteousness all day long,
for those who intend to harm me
will be disgraced and confounded.

chapter.head2: Of Solomon.

poem.verse: 1God, give your justice to the king

poetryblock.poem: and your righteousness to the king’s son.

poem.verse: 2He will judge your people with righteousness

poetryblock.poem: and your afflicted ones with justice.

poem.verse: 3May the mountains bring well-being to the people

poetryblock.poem: and the hills, righteousness.

poem.verse: 4May he vindicate the afflicted among the people,

poetryblock.poem: help the poor,
and crush the oppressor.

poem.verse: 5May they fear you while the sun endures

poetryblock.poem: and as long as the moon, throughout all generations.

poem.verse: 6May the king be like rain that falls on the cut grass,

poetryblock.poem: like spring showers that water the earth.

poem.verse: 7May the righteous flourish in his days

poetryblock.poem: and well-being abound
until the moon is no more.

poem.verse: 8May he rule from sea to sea

poetryblock.poem: and from the Euphrates
to the ends of the earth.

poem.verse: 9May desert tribes kneel before him

poetryblock.poem: and his enemies lick the dust.

poem.verse: 10May the kings of Tarshish

poetryblock.poem: and the coasts and islands bring tribute,
the kings of Sheba and Seba offer gifts.

poem.verse: 11Let all kings bow in homage to him,

poetryblock.poem: all nations serve him.

poem.verse: 12For he will rescue the poor who cry out

poetryblock.poem: and the afflicted who have no helper.

poem.verse: 13He will have pity on the poor and helpless

poetryblock.poem: and save the lives of the poor.

poem.verse: 14He will redeem them from oppression and violence,

poetryblock.poem: for their lives are precious in his sight.

poem.verse: 15May he live long!

poetryblock.poem: May gold from Sheba be given to him.
May prayer be offered for him continually,
and may he be blessed all day long.

poem.verse: 16May there be plenty of corn in the land;

poetryblock.poem: may it wave on the tops of the mountains.
May its crops be like Lebanon.
May people flourish in the cities
like the grass of the field.

poem.verse: 17May his name endure for ever;

poetryblock.poem: as long as the sun shines,
may his fame increase.
May all nations be blessed by him
and call him blessed.

poem.verse: 18Blessed be the Lord God, the God of Israel,

poetryblock.poem: who alone does wonders.

poem.verse: 19Blessed be his glorious name for ever;

poetryblock.poem: the whole earth is filled with his glory.
Amen and amen.

poem.verse: 20The prayers of David son of Jesse are concluded.

chapter.head2: A psalm of Asaph.

poem.verse: 1God is indeed good to Israel,

poetryblock.poem: to the pure in heart.

poem.verse: 2But as for me, my feet almost slipped;

poetryblock.poem: my steps nearly went astray.

poem.verse: 3For I envied the arrogant;

poetryblock.poem: I saw the prosperity of the wicked.

poem.verse: 4They have an easy time until they die,

poetryblock.poem: and their bodies are well fed.

poem.verse: 5They are not in trouble like others;

poetryblock.poem: they are not afflicted like most people.

poem.verse: 6Therefore, pride is their necklace,

poetryblock.poem: and violence covers them like a garment.

poem.verse: 7Their eyes bulge out from fatness;

poetryblock.poem: the imaginations of their hearts run wild.

poem.verse: 8They mock, and they speak maliciously;

poetryblock.poem: they arrogantly threaten oppression.

poem.verse: 9They set their mouths against heaven,

poetryblock.poem: and their tongues strut across the earth.

poem.verse: 10Therefore his people turn to them

poetryblock.poem: and drink in their overflowing words.

poem.verse: 11The wicked say, ‘How can God know?

poetryblock.poem: Does the Most High know everything? ’

poem.verse: 12Look at them ​– ​the wicked!

poetryblock.poem: They are always at ease,
and they increase their wealth.

poem.verse: 13Did I purify my heart

poetryblock.poem: and wash my hands in innocence for nothing?

poem.verse: 14For I am afflicted all day long

poetryblock.poem: and punished every morning.

poem.verse: 15If I had decided to say these things aloud,

poetryblock.poem: I would have betrayed your people.

poem.verse: 16When I tried to understand all this,

poetryblock.poem: it seemed hopeless

poem.verse: 17until I entered God’s sanctuary.

poetryblock.poem: Then I understood their destiny.

poem.verse: 18Indeed, you put them in slippery places;

poetryblock.poem: you make them fall into ruin.

poem.verse: 19How suddenly they become a desolation!

poetryblock.poem: They come to an end, swept away by terrors.

poem.verse: 20Like one waking from a dream,

poetryblock.poem: Lord, when arising, you will despise their image.

poem.verse: 21When I became embittered

poetryblock.poem: and my innermost being was wounded,

poem.verse: 22I was stupid and didn’t understand;

poetryblock.poem: I was an unthinking animal towards you.

poem.verse: 23Yet I am always with you;

poetryblock.poem: you hold my right hand.

poem.verse: 24You guide me with your counsel,

poetryblock.poem: and afterwards you will take me up in glory.

poem.verse: 25Who do I have in heaven but you?

poetryblock.poem: And I desire nothing on earth but you.

poem.verse: 26My flesh and my heart may fail,

poetryblock.poem: but God is the strength of my heart,
my portion for ever.

poem.verse: 27Those far from you will certainly perish;

poetryblock.poem: you destroy all who are unfaithful to you.

poem.verse: 28But as for me, God’s presence is my good.

poetryblock.poem: I have made the Lord God my refuge,
so I can tell about all you do.

chapter.head2: A 'Maskil' of Asaph.

poem.verse: 1Why have you rejected us for ever, God?

poetryblock.poem: Why does your anger burn
against the sheep of your pasture?

poem.verse: 2Remember your congregation,

poetryblock.poem: which you purchased long ago
and redeemed as the tribe for your own possession.
Remember Mount Zion where you dwell.

poem.verse: 3Make your way to the perpetual ruins,

poetryblock.poem: to all that the enemy has destroyed in the sanctuary.

poem.verse: 4Your adversaries roared in the meeting place

poetryblock.poem: where you met with us.
They set up their emblems as signs.

poem.verse: 5It was like men in a thicket of trees,

poetryblock.poem: wielding axes,

poem.verse: 6then smashing all the carvings

poetryblock.poem: with hatchets and picks.

poem.verse: 7They set your sanctuary on fire;

poetryblock.poem: they utterly desecrated
the dwelling place of your name.

poem.verse: 8They said in their hearts,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Let’s oppress them relentlessly.’
They burned every place throughout the land
where God met with us.

poem.verse: 9There are no signs for us to see.

poetryblock.poem: There is no longer a prophet.
And none of us knows how long this will last.

poem.verse: 10God, how long will the enemy mock?

poetryblock.poem: Will the foe insult your name for ever?

poem.verse: 11Why do you hold back your hand?

poetryblock.poem: Stretch out your right hand and destroy them!

poem.verse: 12God my King is from ancient times,

poetryblock.poem: performing saving acts on the earth.

poem.verse: 13You divided the sea with your strength;

poetryblock.poem: you smashed the heads of the sea monsters in the water;

poem.verse: 14you crushed the heads of Leviathan;

poetryblock.poem: you fed him to the creatures of the desert.

poem.verse: 15You opened up springs and streams;

poetryblock.poem: you dried up ever-flowing rivers.

poem.verse: 16The day is yours, also the night;

poetryblock.poem: you established the moon and the sun.

poem.verse: 17You set all the boundaries of the earth;

poetryblock.poem: you made summer and winter.

poem.verse: 18Remember this: the enemy has mocked the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and a foolish people has insulted your name.

poem.verse: 19Do not give to beasts the life of your dove;

poetryblock.poem: do not forget the lives of your poor people for ever.

poem.verse: 20Consider the covenant,

poetryblock.poem: for the dark places of the land are full of violence.

poem.verse: 21Do not let the oppressed turn away in shame;

poetryblock.poem: let the poor and needy praise your name.

poem.verse: 22Rise up, God, champion your cause!

poetryblock.poem: Remember the insults
that fools bring against you all day long.

poem.verse: 23Do not forget the clamour of your adversaries,

poetryblock.poem: the tumult of your opponents that goes up constantly.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: ‘Do Not Destroy.’ A psalm of Asaph. A song.

poem.verse: 1We give thanks to you, God;

poetryblock.poem: we give thanks to you, for your name is near.
People tell about your wondrous works.

poem.verse: 2‘When I choose a time,

poetryblock.poem: I will judge fairly.

poem.verse: 3When the earth and all its inhabitants shake,

poetryblock.poem: I am the one who steadies its pillars.'Selah'

poem.verse: 4I say to the boastful, “Do not boast,”

poetryblock.poem: and to the wicked, “Do not lift up your horn.

poem.verse: 5Do not lift up your horn against heaven

poetryblock.poem: or speak arrogantly.” ’

poem.verse: 6Exaltation does not come

poetryblock.poem: from the east, the west, or the desert,

poem.verse: 7for God is the Judge:

poetryblock.poem: He brings down one and exalts another.

poem.verse: 8For there is a cup in the Lord’s hand,

poetryblock.poem: full of wine blended with spices, and he pours from it.
All the wicked of the earth will drink,
draining it to the dregs.

poem.verse: 9As for me, I will tell about him for ever;

poetryblock.poem: I will sing praise to the God of Jacob.

poem.verse: 10‘I will cut off all the horns of the wicked,

poetryblock.poem: but the horns of the righteous will be lifted up.’

chapter.head2: For the choir director: with stringed instruments. A psalm of Asaph. A song.

poem.verse: 1God is known in Judah;

poetryblock.poem: his name is great in Israel.

poem.verse: 2His tent is in Salem,

poetryblock.poem: his dwelling place in Zion.

poem.verse: 3There he shatters the bow’s flaming arrows,

poetryblock.poem: the shield, the sword, and the weapons of war.'Selah'

poem.verse: 4You are resplendent and majestic

poetryblock.poem: coming down from the mountains of prey.

poem.verse: 5The brave-hearted have been plundered;

poetryblock.poem: they have slipped into their final sleep.
None of the warriors was able to lift a hand.

poem.verse: 6At your rebuke, God of Jacob,

poetryblock.poem: both chariot and horse lay still.

poem.verse: 7And you ​– ​you are to be feared.

poetryblock.poem: When you are angry,
who can stand before you?

poem.verse: 8From heaven you pronounced judgement.

poetryblock.poem: The earth feared and grew quiet

poem.verse: 9when God rose up to judge

poetryblock.poem: and to save all the lowly of the earth.'Selah'

poem.verse: 10Even human wrath will praise you;

poetryblock.poem: you will clothe yourself
with the wrath that remains.

poem.verse: 11Make and keep your vows

poetryblock.poem: to the Lord your God;
let all who are around him bring tribute
to the awe-inspiring one.

poem.verse: 12He humbles the spirit of leaders;

poetryblock.poem: he is feared by the kings of the earth.

chapter.head1: Confidence in a Time of Crisis
chapter.head2: For the choir director: according to Jeduthun. Of Asaph. A psalm.

poem.verse: 1I cry aloud to God,

poetryblock.poem: aloud to God, and he will hear me.

poem.verse: 2I sought the Lord in my day of trouble.

poetryblock.poem: My hands were continually lifted up
all night long;
I refused to be comforted.

poem.verse: 3I think of God; I groan;

poetryblock.poem: I meditate; my spirit becomes weak.'Selah'

poem.verse: 4You have kept me from closing my eyes;

poetryblock.poem: I am troubled and cannot speak.

poem.verse: 5I consider days of old,

poetryblock.poem: years long past.

poem.verse: 6At night I remember my music;

poetryblock.poem: I meditate in my heart, and my spirit ponders.

poem.verse: 7‘Will the Lord reject for ever

poetryblock.poem: and never again show favour?

poem.verse: 8Has his faithful love ceased for ever?

poetryblock.poem: Is his promise at an end for all generations?

poem.verse: 9Has God forgotten to be gracious?

poetryblock.poem: Has he in anger withheld his compassion? ’'Selah'

poem.verse: 10So I say, ‘I am grieved

poetryblock.poem: that the right hand of the Most High has changed.’

poem.verse: 11I will remember the Lord’s works;

poetryblock.poem: yes, I will remember your ancient wonders.

poem.verse: 12I will reflect on all you have done

poetryblock.poem: and meditate on your actions.

poem.verse: 13God, your way is holy.

poetryblock.poem: What god is great like God?

poem.verse: 14You are the God who works wonders;

poetryblock.poem: you revealed your strength among the peoples.

poem.verse: 15With power you redeemed your people,

poetryblock.poem: the descendants of Jacob and Joseph.'Selah'

poem.verse: 16The water saw you, God.

poetryblock.poem: The water saw you; it trembled.
Even the depths shook.

poem.verse: 17The clouds poured down water.

poetryblock.poem: The storm clouds thundered;
your arrows flashed back and forth.

poem.verse: 18The sound of your thunder was in the whirlwind;

poetryblock.poem: lightning lit up the world.
The earth shook and quaked.

poem.verse: 19Your way went through the sea

poetryblock.poem: and your path through the vast water,
but your footprints were unseen.

poem.verse: 20You led your people like a flock

poetryblock.poem: by the hand of Moses and Aaron.

chapter.head2: A 'Maskil' of Asaph.

poem.verse: 1My people, hear my instruction;

poetryblock.poem: listen to the words from my mouth.

poem.verse: 2I will declare wise sayings;

poetryblock.poem: I will speak mysteries from the past –

poem.verse: 3things we have heard and known

poetryblock.poem: and that our ancestors have passed down to us.

poem.verse: 4We will not hide them from their children,

poetryblock.poem: but will tell a future generation
the praiseworthy acts of the Lord,
his might, and the wondrous works
he has performed.

poem.verse: 5He established a testimony in Jacob

poetryblock.poem: and set up a law in Israel,
which he commanded our ancestors
to teach to their children

poem.verse: 6so that a future generation –

poetryblock.poem: children yet to be born ​– ​might know.
They were to rise and tell their children

poem.verse: 7so that they might put their confidence in God

poetryblock.poem: and not forget God’s works,
but keep his commands.

poem.verse: 8Then they would not be like their ancestors,

poetryblock.poem: a stubborn and rebellious generation,
a generation whose heart was not loyal
and whose spirit was not faithful to God.

poem.verse: 9The Ephraimite archers turned back

poetryblock.poem: on the day of battle.

poem.verse: 10They did not keep God’s covenant

poetryblock.poem: and refused to live by his law.

poem.verse: 11They forgot what he had done,

poetryblock.poem: the wondrous works he had shown them.

poem.verse: 12He worked wonders in the sight of their ancestors

poetryblock.poem: in the land of Egypt, the territory of Zoan.

poem.verse: 13He split the sea and brought them across;

poetryblock.poem: the water stood firm like a wall.

poem.verse: 14He led them with a cloud by day

poetryblock.poem: and with a fiery light throughout the night.

poem.verse: 15He split rocks in the wilderness

poetryblock.poem: and gave them drink as abundant as the depths.

poem.verse: 16He brought streams out of the stone

poetryblock.poem: and made water flow down like rivers.

poem.verse: 17But they continued to sin against him,

poetryblock.poem: rebelling in the desert against the Most High.

poem.verse: 18They deliberately tested God,

poetryblock.poem: demanding the food they craved.

poem.verse: 19They spoke against God, saying,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Is God able to provide food in the wilderness?

poem.verse: 20Look! He struck the rock and water gushed out;

poetryblock.poem: torrents overflowed.
But can he also provide bread
or furnish meat for his people? ’

poem.verse: 21Therefore, the Lord heard and became furious;

poetryblock.poem: then fire broke out against Jacob,
and anger flared up against Israel

poem.verse: 22because they did not believe God

poetryblock.poem: or rely on his salvation.

poem.verse: 23He gave a command to the clouds above

poetryblock.poem: and opened the doors of heaven.

poem.verse: 24He rained manna for them to eat;

poetryblock.poem: he gave them grain from heaven.

poem.verse: 25People ate the bread of angels.

poetryblock.poem: He sent them an abundant supply of food.

poem.verse: 26He made the east wind blow in the skies

poetryblock.poem: and drove the south wind by his might.

poem.verse: 27He rained meat on them like dust,

poetryblock.poem: and winged birds like the sand of the seas.

poem.verse: 28He made them fall in the camp,

poetryblock.poem: all around the tents.

poem.verse: 29The people ate and were completely satisfied,

poetryblock.poem: for he gave them what they craved.

poem.verse: 30Before they had turned from what they craved,

poetryblock.poem: while the food was still in their mouths,

poem.verse: 31God’s anger flared up against them,

poetryblock.poem: and he killed some of their best men.
He struck down Israel’s fit young men.

poem.verse: 32Despite all this, they kept sinning

poetryblock.poem: and did not believe his wondrous works.

poem.verse: 33He made their days end in futility,

poetryblock.poem: their years in sudden disaster.

poem.verse: 34When he killed some of them,

poetryblock.poem: the rest began to seek him;
they repented and searched for God.

poem.verse: 35They remembered that God was their rock,

poetryblock.poem: the Most High God, their Redeemer.

poem.verse: 36But they deceived him with their mouths,

poetryblock.poem: they lied to him with their tongues,

poem.verse: 37their hearts were insincere towards him,

poetryblock.poem: and they were unfaithful to his covenant.

poem.verse: 38Yet he was compassionate;

poetryblock.poem: he atoned for their iniquity
and did not destroy them.
He often turned his anger aside
and did not unleash all his wrath.

poem.verse: 39He remembered that they were only flesh,

poetryblock.poem: a wind that passes and does not return.

poem.verse: 40How often they rebelled against him

poetryblock.poem: in the wilderness
and grieved him in the desert.

poem.verse: 41They constantly tested God

poetryblock.poem: and provoked the Holy One of Israel.

poem.verse: 42They did not remember his power shown

poetryblock.poem: on the day he redeemed them from the foe,

poem.verse: 43when he performed his miraculous signs in Egypt

poetryblock.poem: and his wonders in the territory of Zoan.

poem.verse: 44He turned their rivers into blood,

poetryblock.poem: and they could not drink from their streams.

poem.verse: 45He sent among them swarms of flies,

poetryblock.poem: which fed on them,
and frogs, which devastated them.

poem.verse: 46He gave their crops to the caterpillar

poetryblock.poem: and the fruit of their labour to the locust.

poem.verse: 47He killed their vines with hail

poetryblock.poem: and their sycamore fig trees with a flood.

poem.verse: 48He handed over their livestock to hail

poetryblock.poem: and their cattle to lightning bolts.

poem.verse: 49He sent his burning anger against them:

poetryblock.poem: fury, indignation, and calamity –
a band of deadly messengers.

poem.verse: 50He cleared a path for his anger.

poetryblock.poem: He did not spare them from death
but delivered their lives to the plague.

poem.verse: 51He struck all the firstborn in Egypt,

poetryblock.poem: the first progeny of the tents of Ham.

poem.verse: 52He led his people out like sheep

poetryblock.poem: and guided them like a flock in the wilderness.

poem.verse: 53He led them safely, and they were not afraid;

poetryblock.poem: but the sea covered their enemies.

poem.verse: 54He brought them to his holy territory,

poetryblock.poem: to the mountain his right hand acquired.

poem.verse: 55He drove out nations before them.

poetryblock.poem: He apportioned their inheritance by lot
and settled the tribes of Israel in their tents.

poem.verse: 56But they rebelliously tested the Most High God,

poetryblock.poem: for they did not keep his decrees.

poem.verse: 57They treacherously turned away like their ancestors;

poetryblock.poem: they became warped like a faulty bow.

poem.verse: 58They enraged him with their high places

poetryblock.poem: and provoked his jealousy with their carved images.

poem.verse: 59God heard and became furious;

poetryblock.poem: he completely rejected Israel.

poem.verse: 60He abandoned the tabernacle at Shiloh,

poetryblock.poem: the tent where he resided among mankind.

poem.verse: 61He gave up his strength to captivity

poetryblock.poem: and his splendour to the hand of a foe.

poem.verse: 62He surrendered his people to the sword

poetryblock.poem: because he was enraged with his heritage.

poem.verse: 63Fire consumed his chosen young men,

poetryblock.poem: and his young women had no wedding songs.

poem.verse: 64His priests fell by the sword,

poetryblock.poem: and the widows could not lament.

poem.verse: 65The Lord awoke as if from sleep,

poetryblock.poem: like a warrior from the effects of wine.

poem.verse: 66He beat back his foes;

poetryblock.poem: he gave them lasting disgrace.

poem.verse: 67He rejected the tent of Joseph

poetryblock.poem: and did not choose the tribe of Ephraim.

poem.verse: 68He chose instead the tribe of Judah,

poetryblock.poem: Mount Zion, which he loved.

poem.verse: 69He built his sanctuary like the heights,

poetryblock.poem: like the earth that he established for ever.

poem.verse: 70He chose David his servant

poetryblock.poem: and took him from the sheepfolds;

poem.verse: 71he brought him from tending ewes

poetryblock.poem: to be shepherd over his people Jacob –
over Israel, his inheritance.

poem.verse: 72He shepherded them with a pure heart

poetryblock.poem: and guided them with his skilful hands.

chapter.head2: A psalm of Asaph.

poem.verse: 1God, the nations have invaded your inheritance,

poetryblock.poem: desecrated your holy temple,
and turned Jerusalem into ruins.

poem.verse: 2They gave the corpses of your servants

poetryblock.poem: to the birds of the sky for food,
the flesh of your faithful ones
to the beasts of the earth.

poem.verse: 3They poured out their blood

poetryblock.poem: like water all around Jerusalem,
and there was no one to bury them.

poem.verse: 4We have become an object of reproach

poetryblock.poem: to our neighbours,
a source of mockery and ridicule
to those around us.

poem.verse: 5How long, Lord? Will you be angry for ever?

poetryblock.poem: Will your jealousy keep burning like fire?

poem.verse: 6Pour out your wrath on the nations

poetryblock.poem: that don’t acknowledge you,
on the kingdoms that don’t call on your name,

poem.verse: 7for they have devoured Jacob

poetryblock.poem: and devastated his homeland.

poem.verse: 8Do not hold past iniquities against us;

poetryblock.poem: let your compassion come to us quickly,
for we have become very weak.

poem.verse: 9God of our salvation, help us,

poetryblock.poem: for the glory of your name.
Rescue us and atone for our sins,
for your name’s sake.

poem.verse: 10Why should the nations ask,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Where is their God? ’
Before our eyes,
let vengeance for the shed blood of your servants
be known among the nations.

poem.verse: 11Let the groans of the prisoners reach you;

poetryblock.poem: according to your great power,
preserve those condemned to die.

poem.verse: 12Pay back sevenfold to our neighbours

poetryblock.poem: the reproach they have hurled at you, Lord.

poem.verse: 13Then we, your people, the sheep of your pasture,

poetryblock.poem: will thank you for ever;
we will declare your praise
to generation after generation.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: according to ‘The Lilies.’ A testimony of Asaph. A psalm.

poem.verse: 1Listen, Shepherd of Israel,

poetryblock.poem: who leads Joseph like a flock;
