you who sit enthroned between the cherubim,
shine 2on Ephraim,
Benjamin, and Manasseh.
Rally your power and come to save us.

poem.verse: 3Restore us, God;

poetryblock.poem: make your face shine on us,
so that we may be saved.

poem.verse: 4Lord God of Armies,

poetryblock.poem: how long will you be angry
with your people’s prayers?

poem.verse: 5You fed them the bread of tears

poetryblock.poem: and gave them a full measure
of tears to drink.

poem.verse: 6You put us at odds with our neighbours;

poetryblock.poem: our enemies mock us.

poem.verse: 7Restore us, God of Armies;

poetryblock.poem: make your face shine on us, so that we may be saved.

poem.verse: 8You dug up a vine from Egypt;

poetryblock.poem: you drove out the nations and planted it.

poem.verse: 9You cleared a place for it;

poetryblock.poem: it took root and filled the land.

poem.verse: 10The mountains were covered by its shade,

poetryblock.poem: and the mighty cedars with its branches.

poem.verse: 11It sent out branches towards the Sea

poetryblock.poem: and shoots towards the River.

poem.verse: 12Why have you broken down its walls

poetryblock.poem: so that all who pass by pick its fruit?

poem.verse: 13Boars from the forest tear at it

poetryblock.poem: and creatures of the field feed on it.

poem.verse: 14Return, God of Armies.

poetryblock.poem: Look down from heaven and see;
take care of this vine,

poem.verse: 15the root your right hand planted,

poetryblock.poem: the son that you made strong for yourself.

poem.verse: 16It was cut down and burned;

poetryblock.poem: they perish at the rebuke of your countenance.

poem.verse: 17Let your hand be with the man at your right hand,

poetryblock.poem: with the son of man
you have made strong for yourself.

poem.verse: 18Then we will not turn away from you;

poetryblock.poem: revive us, and we will call on your name.

poem.verse: 19Restore us, Lord, God of Armies;

poetryblock.poem: make your face shine on us, so that we may be saved.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: on the 'Gittith'. Of Asaph.

poem.verse: 1Sing for joy to God our strength;

poetryblock.poem: shout in triumph to the God of Jacob.

poem.verse: 2Lift up a song ​– ​play the tambourine,

poetryblock.poem: the melodious lyre, and the harp.

poem.verse: 3Blow the ram’s horn on the day of our feasts

poetryblock.poem: during the new moon
and during the full moon.

poem.verse: 4For this is a statute for Israel,

poetryblock.poem: an ordinance of the God of Jacob.

poem.verse: 5He set it up as a decree for Joseph

poetryblock.poem: when he went throughout the land of Egypt.
I heard an unfamiliar language:

poem.verse: 6‘I relieved his shoulder from the burden;

poetryblock.poem: his hands were freed from carrying the basket.

poem.verse: 7You called out in distress, and I rescued you;

poetryblock.poem: I answered you from the thundercloud.
I tested you at the Waters of Meribah.'Selah'

poem.verse: 8Listen, my people, and I will admonish you.

poetryblock.poem: Israel, if you would only listen to me!

poem.verse: 9There must not be a strange god among you;

poetryblock.poem: you must not bow down to a foreign god.

poem.verse: 10I am the Lord your God,

poetryblock.poem: who brought you up from the land of Egypt.
Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it.

poem.verse: 11‘But my people did not listen to my voice;

poetryblock.poem: Israel did not obey me.

poem.verse: 12So I gave them over to their stubborn hearts

poetryblock.poem: to follow their own plans.

poem.verse: 13If only my people would listen to me

poetryblock.poem: and Israel would follow my ways,

poem.verse: 14I would quickly subdue their enemies

poetryblock.poem: and turn my hand against their foes.’

poem.verse: 15Those who hate the Lord

poetryblock.poem: would cower to him;
their doom would last for ever.

poem.verse: 16But he would feed Israel with the best wheat.

poetryblock.poem: ‘I would satisfy you with honey from the rock.’

chapter.head2: A psalm of Asaph.

poem.verse: 1God stands in the divine assembly;

poetryblock.poem: he pronounces judgement among the gods:

poem.verse: 2‘How long will you judge unjustly

poetryblock.poem: and show partiality to the wicked?'Selah'

poem.verse: 3Provide justice for the needy and the fatherless;

poetryblock.poem: uphold the rights of the oppressed and the destitute.

poem.verse: 4Rescue the poor and needy;

poetryblock.poem: save them from the power of the wicked.’

poem.verse: 5They do not know or understand;

poetryblock.poem: they wander in darkness.
All the foundations of the earth are shaken.

poem.verse: 6I said, ‘You are gods;

poetryblock.poem: you are all sons of the Most High.

poem.verse: 7However, you will die like humans

poetryblock.poem: and fall like any other ruler.’

poem.verse: 8Rise up, God, judge the earth,

poetryblock.poem: for all the nations belong to you.

chapter.head2: A song. A psalm of Asaph.

poem.verse: 1God, do not keep silent.

poetryblock.poem: Do not be deaf, God; do not be quiet.

poem.verse: 2See how your enemies make an uproar;

poetryblock.poem: those who hate you have acted arrogantly.

poem.verse: 3They devise clever schemes against your people;

poetryblock.poem: they conspire against your treasured ones.

poem.verse: 4They say, ‘Come, let’s wipe them out as a nation

poetryblock.poem: so that Israel’s name will no longer be remembered.’

poem.verse: 5For they have conspired with one mind;

poetryblock.poem: they form an alliance against you –

poem.verse: 6the tents of Edom and the Ishmaelites,

poetryblock.poem: Moab and the Hagrites,

poem.verse: 7Gebal, Ammon, and Amalek,

poetryblock.poem: Philistia with the inhabitants of Tyre.

poem.verse: 8Even Assyria has joined them;

poetryblock.poem: they lend support to the sons of Lot.'Selah'

poem.verse: 9Deal with them as you did with Midian,

poetryblock.poem: as you did with Sisera
and Jabin at the River Kishon.

poem.verse: 10They were destroyed at En-dor;

poetryblock.poem: they became manure for the ground.

poem.verse: 11Make their nobles like Oreb and Zeeb,

poetryblock.poem: and all their tribal leaders like Zebah and Zalmunna,

poem.verse: 12who said, ‘Let’s seize God’s pastures for ourselves.’
13Make them like tumbleweed, my God,

poetryblock.poem: like straw before the wind.

poem.verse: 14As fire burns a forest,

poetryblock.poem: as a flame blazes through mountains,

poem.verse: 15so pursue them with your tempest

poetryblock.poem: and terrify them with your storm.

poem.verse: 16Cover their faces with shame

poetryblock.poem: so that they will seek your name, Lord.

poem.verse: 17Let them be put to shame and terrified for ever;

poetryblock.poem: let them perish in disgrace.

poem.verse: 18May they know that you alone –

poetryblock.poem: whose name is the Lord –
are the Most High over the whole earth.

chapter.head2: For the choir director: on the 'Gittith'. A psalm of the sons of Korah.

poem.verse: 1How lovely is your dwelling place,

poetryblock.poem: Lord of Armies.

poem.verse: 2I long and yearn

poetryblock.poem: for the courts of the Lord;
my heart and flesh cry out for the living God.

poem.verse: 3Even a sparrow finds a home,

poetryblock.poem: and a swallow, a nest for herself
where she places her young –
near your altars, Lord of Armies,
my King and my God.

poem.verse: 4How happy are those who reside in your house,

poetryblock.poem: who praise you continually.'Selah'

poem.verse: 5Happy are the people whose strength is in you,

poetryblock.poem: whose hearts are set on pilgrimage.

poem.verse: 6As they pass through the Valley of Baca,

poetryblock.poem: they make it a source of spring water;
even the autumn rain will cover it with blessings.

poem.verse: 7They go from strength to strength;

poetryblock.poem: each appears before God in Zion.

poem.verse: 8Lord God of Armies, hear my prayer;

poetryblock.poem: listen, God of Jacob.'Selah'

poem.verse: 9Consider our shield, God;

poetryblock.poem: look on the face of your anointed one.

poem.verse: 10Better a day in your courts

poetryblock.poem: than a thousand anywhere else.
I would rather stand at the threshold of the house of my God
than live in the tents of wicked people.

poem.verse: 11For the Lord God is a sun and shield.

poetryblock.poem: The Lord grants favour and honour;
he does not withhold the good
from those who live with integrity.

poem.verse: 12Happy is the person who trusts in you,

poetryblock.poem: Lord of Armies!

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A psalm of the sons of Korah.

poem.verse: 1Lord, you showed favour to your land;

poetryblock.poem: you restored the fortunes of Jacob.

poem.verse: 2You forgave your people’s guilt;

poetryblock.poem: you covered all their sin.'Selah'

poem.verse: 3You withdrew all your fury;

poetryblock.poem: you turned from your burning anger.

poem.verse: 4Return to us, God of our salvation,

poetryblock.poem: and abandon your displeasure with us.

poem.verse: 5Will you be angry with us for ever?

poetryblock.poem: Will you prolong your anger for all generations?

poem.verse: 6Will you not revive us again

poetryblock.poem: so that your people may rejoice in you?

poem.verse: 7Show us your faithful love, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and give us your salvation.

poem.verse: 8I will listen to what God will say;

poetryblock.poem: surely the Lord will declare peace
to his people, his faithful ones,
and not let them go back to foolish ways.

poem.verse: 9His salvation is very near to those who fear him,

poetryblock.poem: so that glory may dwell in our land.

poem.verse: 10Faithful love and truth will join together;

poetryblock.poem: righteousness and peace will embrace.

poem.verse: 11Truth will spring up from the earth,

poetryblock.poem: and righteousness will look down from heaven.

poem.verse: 12Also, the Lord will provide what is good,

poetryblock.poem: and our land will yield its crops.

poem.verse: 13Righteousness will go before him

poetryblock.poem: to prepare the way for his steps.

chapter.head2: A prayer of David.

poem.verse: 1Listen, Lord, and answer me,

poetryblock.poem: for I am poor and needy.

poem.verse: 2Protect my life, for I am faithful.

poetryblock.poem: You are my God; save your servant who trusts in you.

poem.verse: 3Be gracious to me, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: for I call to you all day long.

poem.verse: 4Bring joy to your servant’s life,

poetryblock.poem: because I appeal to you, Lord.

poem.verse: 5For you, Lord, are kind and ready to forgive,

poetryblock.poem: abounding in faithful love to all who call on you.

poem.verse: 6Lord, hear my prayer;

poetryblock.poem: listen to my cries for mercy.

poem.verse: 7I call on you in the day of my distress,

poetryblock.poem: for you will answer me.

poem.verse: 8Lord, there is no one like you among the gods,

poetryblock.poem: and there are no works like yours.

poem.verse: 9All the nations you have made

poetryblock.poem: will come and bow down before you, Lord,
and will honour your name.

poem.verse: 10For you are great and perform wonders;

poetryblock.poem: you alone are God.

poem.verse: 11Teach me your way, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and I will live by your truth.
Give me an undivided mind to fear your name.

poem.verse: 12I will praise you with all my heart, Lord my God,

poetryblock.poem: and will honour your name for ever.

poem.verse: 13For your faithful love for me is great,

poetryblock.poem: and you rescue my life from the depths of Sheol.

poem.verse: 14God, arrogant people have attacked me;

poetryblock.poem: a gang of ruthless men intends to kill me.
They do not let you guide them.

poem.verse: 15But you, Lord, are a compassionate and gracious God,

poetryblock.poem: slow to anger and abounding in faithful love and truth.

poem.verse: 16Turn to me and be gracious to me.

poetryblock.poem: Give your strength to your servant;
save the son of your female servant.

poem.verse: 17Show me a sign of your goodness;

poetryblock.poem: my enemies will see and be put to shame
because you, Lord, have helped and comforted me.

chapter.head2: A psalm of the sons of Korah. A song.

poem.verse: 1The city he founded is on the holy mountains.
2The Lord loves Zion’s city gates

poetryblock.poem: more than all the dwellings of Jacob.

poem.verse: 3Glorious things are said about you,

poetryblock.poem: city of God.'Selah'

poem.verse: 4‘I will make a record of those who know me:

poetryblock.poem: Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Cush –
each one was born there.’

poem.verse: 5And it will be said of Zion,

poetryblock.poem: ‘This one and that one were born in her.’
The Most High himself will establish her.

poem.verse: 6When he registers the peoples,

poetryblock.poem: the Lord will record,
‘This one was born there.’'Selah'

poem.verse: 7Singers and dancers alike will say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘My whole source of joy is in you.’

chapter.head2: A song. A psalm of the sons of Korah. For the choir director: according to 'Mahalath Leannoth.' A 'Maskil' of Heman the Ezrahite.

poem.verse: 1Lord, God of my salvation,

poetryblock.poem: I cry out before you day and night.

poem.verse: 2May my prayer reach your presence;

poetryblock.poem: listen to my cry.

poem.verse: 3For I have had enough troubles,

poetryblock.poem: and my life is near Sheol.

poem.verse: 4I am counted among those going down to the Pit.

poetryblock.poem: I am like a man without strength,

poem.verse: 5abandoned among the dead.

poetryblock.poem: I am like the slain lying in the grave,
whom you no longer remember,
and who are cut off from your care.

poem.verse: 6You have put me in the lowest part of the Pit,

poetryblock.poem: in the darkest places, in the depths.

poem.verse: 7Your wrath weighs heavily on me;

poetryblock.poem: you have overwhelmed me with all your waves.'Selah'

poem.verse: 8You have distanced my friends from me;

poetryblock.poem: you have made me repulsive to them.
I am shut in and cannot go out.

poem.verse: 9My eyes are worn out from crying.

poetryblock.poem: Lord, I cry out to you all day long;
I spread out my hands to you.

poem.verse: 10Do you work wonders for the dead?

poetryblock.poem: Do departed spirits rise up to praise you?'Selah'

poem.verse: 11Will your faithful love be declared in the grave,

poetryblock.poem: your faithfulness in Abaddon?

poem.verse: 12Will your wonders be known in the darkness

poetryblock.poem: or your righteousness in the land of oblivion?

poem.verse: 13But I call to you for help, Lord;

poetryblock.poem: in the morning my prayer meets you.

poem.verse: 14Lord, why do you reject me?

poetryblock.poem: Why do you hide your face from me?

poem.verse: 15From my youth,

poetryblock.poem: I have been suffering and near death.
I suffer your horrors; I am desperate.

poem.verse: 16Your wrath sweeps over me;

poetryblock.poem: your terrors destroy me.

poem.verse: 17They surround me like water all day long;

poetryblock.poem: they close in on me from every side.

poem.verse: 18You have distanced loved one and neighbour from me;

poetryblock.poem: darkness is my only friend.

chapter.head2: A 'Maskil' of Ethan the Ezrahite.

poem.verse: 1I will sing about the Lord’s faithful love for ever;

poetryblock.poem: I will proclaim your faithfulness to all generations
with my mouth.

poem.verse: 2For I will declare,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Faithful love is built up for ever;
you establish your faithfulness in the heavens.’

poem.verse: 3The Lord said,

poetryblock.poem: ‘I have made a covenant with my chosen one;
I have sworn an oath to David my servant:

poem.verse: 4“I will establish your offspring for ever

poetryblock.poem: and build up your throne for all generations.” ’'Selah'

poem.verse: 5Lord, the heavens praise your wonders –

poetryblock.poem: your faithfulness also –
in the assembly of the holy ones.

poem.verse: 6For who in the skies can compare with the Lord?

poetryblock.poem: Who among the heavenly beings is like the Lord?

poem.verse: 7God is greatly feared in the council of the holy ones,

poetryblock.poem: more awe-inspiring than all who surround him.

poem.verse: 8Lord God of Armies,

poetryblock.poem: who is strong like you, Lord?
Your faithfulness surrounds you.

poem.verse: 9You rule the raging sea;

poetryblock.poem: when its waves surge, you still them.

poem.verse: 10You crushed Rahab like one who is slain;

poetryblock.poem: you scattered your enemies with your powerful arm.

poem.verse: 11The heavens are yours; the earth also is yours.

poetryblock.poem: The world and everything in it ​– ​you founded them.

poem.verse: 12North and south ​– ​you created them.

poetryblock.poem: Tabor and Hermon shout for joy at your name.

poem.verse: 13You have a mighty arm;

poetryblock.poem: your hand is powerful;
your right hand is lifted high.

poem.verse: 14Righteousness and justice are the foundation

poetryblock.poem: of your throne;
faithful love and truth go before you.

poem.verse: 15Happy are the people who know the joyful shout;

poetryblock.poem: Lord, they walk in the light from your face.

poem.verse: 16They rejoice in your name all day long,

poetryblock.poem: and they are exalted by your righteousness.

poem.verse: 17For you are their magnificent strength;

poetryblock.poem: by your favour our horn is exalted.

poem.verse: 18Surely our shield belongs to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: our king to the Holy One of Israel.

poem.verse: 19You once spoke in a vision to your faithful ones

poetryblock.poem: and said, ‘I have granted help to a warrior;
I have exalted one chosen from the people.

poem.verse: 20I have found David my servant;

poetryblock.poem: I have anointed him with my sacred oil.

poem.verse: 21My hand will always be with him,

poetryblock.poem: and my arm will strengthen him.

poem.verse: 22The enemy will not oppress him;

poetryblock.poem: the wicked will not afflict him.

poem.verse: 23I will crush his foes before him

poetryblock.poem: and strike those who hate him.

poem.verse: 24My faithfulness and love will be with him,

poetryblock.poem: and through my name
his horn will be exalted.

poem.verse: 25I will extend his power to the sea

poetryblock.poem: and his right hand to the rivers.

poem.verse: 26He will call to me, “You are my Father,

poetryblock.poem: my God, the rock of my salvation.”

poem.verse: 27I will also make him my firstborn,

poetryblock.poem: greatest of the kings of the earth.

poem.verse: 28I will always preserve my faithful love for him,

poetryblock.poem: and my covenant with him will endure.

poem.verse: 29I will establish his line for ever,

poetryblock.poem: his throne as long as heaven lasts.

poem.verse: 30If his sons abandon my instruction

poetryblock.poem: and do not live by my ordinances,

poem.verse: 31if they dishonour my statutes

poetryblock.poem: and do not keep my commands,

poem.verse: 32then I will call their rebellion

poetryblock.poem: to account with the rod,
their iniquity with blows.

poem.verse: 33But I will not withdraw

poetryblock.poem: my faithful love from him
or betray my faithfulness.

poem.verse: 34I will not violate my covenant

poetryblock.poem: or change what my lips have said.

poem.verse: 35Once and for all

poetryblock.poem: I have sworn an oath by my holiness;
I will not lie to David.

poem.verse: 36His offspring will continue for ever,

poetryblock.poem: his throne like the sun before me,

poem.verse: 37like the moon, established for ever,

poetryblock.poem: a faithful witness in the sky.’'Selah'

poem.verse: 38But you have spurned and rejected him;

poetryblock.poem: you have become enraged with your anointed.

poem.verse: 39You have repudiated the covenant with your servant;

poetryblock.poem: you have completely dishonoured his crown.

poem.verse: 40You have broken down all his walls;

poetryblock.poem: you have reduced his fortified cities to ruins.

poem.verse: 41All who pass by plunder him;

poetryblock.poem: he has become an object of ridicule
to his neighbours.

poem.verse: 42You have lifted high the right hand of his foes;

poetryblock.poem: you have made all his enemies rejoice.

poem.verse: 43You have also turned back his sharp sword

poetryblock.poem: and have not let him stand in battle.

poem.verse: 44You have made his splendour cease

poetryblock.poem: and have overturned his throne.

poem.verse: 45You have shortened the days of his youth;

poetryblock.poem: you have covered him with shame.'Selah'

poem.verse: 46How long, Lord? Will you hide for ever?

poetryblock.poem: Will your anger keep burning like fire?

poem.verse: 47Remember how short my life is.

poetryblock.poem: Have you created everyone for nothing?

poem.verse: 48What courageous person can live and never see death?

poetryblock.poem: Who can save himself from the power of Sheol?'Selah'

poem.verse: 49Lord, where are the former acts of your faithful love

poetryblock.poem: that you swore to David in your faithfulness?

poem.verse: 50Remember, Lord, the ridicule against your servants –

poetryblock.poem: in my heart I carry abuse from all the peoples –

poem.verse: 51how your enemies have ridiculed, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: how they have ridiculed every step of your anointed.

poem.verse: 52Blessed be the Lord for ever.

poetryblock.poem: Amen and amen.

chapter.head2: A prayer of Moses, the man of God.

poem.verse: 1Lord, you have been our refuge

poetryblock.poem: in every generation.

poem.verse: 2Before the mountains were born,

poetryblock.poem: before you gave birth to the earth and the world,
from eternity to eternity, you are God.

poem.verse: 3You return mankind to the dust,

poetryblock.poem: saying, ‘Return, descendants of Adam.’

poem.verse: 4For in your sight a thousand years

poetryblock.poem: are like yesterday that passes by,
like a few hours of the night.

poem.verse: 5You end their lives; they sleep.

poetryblock.poem: They are like grass that grows in the morning –

poem.verse: 6in the morning it sprouts and grows;

poetryblock.poem: by the evening it withers and dries up.

poem.verse: 7For we are consumed by your anger;

poetryblock.poem: we are terrified by your wrath.

poem.verse: 8You have set our iniquities before you,

poetryblock.poem: our secret sins in the light of your presence.

poem.verse: 9For all our days ebb away under your wrath;

poetryblock.poem: we end our years like a sigh.

poem.verse: 10Our lives last for seventy years

poetryblock.poem: or, if we are strong, eighty years.
Even the best of them are struggle and sorrow;
indeed, they pass quickly and we fly away.

poem.verse: 11Who understands the power of your anger?

poetryblock.poem: Your wrath matches the fear that is due you.

poem.verse: 12Teach us to number our days carefully

poetryblock.poem: so that we may develop wisdom in our hearts.

poem.verse: 13Lord ​– ​how long?

poetryblock.poem: Turn and have compassion on your servants.

poem.verse: 14Satisfy us in the morning with your faithful love

poetryblock.poem: so that we may shout with joy and be glad all our days.

poem.verse: 15Make us rejoice for as many days as you have humbled us,

poetryblock.poem: for as many years as we have seen adversity.

poem.verse: 16Let your work be seen by your servants,

poetryblock.poem: and your splendour by their children.

poem.verse: 17Let the favour of the Lord our God be on us;

poetryblock.poem: establish for us the work of our hands –
establish the work of our hands!

chapter.head1: The Protection of the Most High

poem.verse: 1The one who lives under the protection of the Most High

poetryblock.poem: dwells in the shadow of the Almighty.

poem.verse: 2I will say concerning the Lord, who is my refuge and my fortress,

poetryblock.poem: my God in whom I trust:

poem.verse: 3He himself will rescue you from the bird trap,

poetryblock.poem: from the destructive plague.

poem.verse: 4He will cover you with his feathers;

poetryblock.poem: you will take refuge under his wings.
His faithfulness will be a protective shield.

poem.verse: 5You will not fear the terror of the night,

poetryblock.poem: the arrow that flies by day,

poem.verse: 6the plague that stalks in darkness,

poetryblock.poem: or the pestilence that ravages at noon.

poem.verse: 7Though a thousand fall at your side

poetryblock.poem: and ten thousand at your right hand,
the pestilence will not reach you.

poem.verse: 8You will only see it with your eyes

poetryblock.poem: and witness the punishment of the wicked.

poem.verse: 9Because you have made the Lord ​– ​my refuge,

poetryblock.poem: the Most High ​– ​your dwelling place,

poem.verse: 10no harm will come to you;

poetryblock.poem: no plague will come near your tent.

poem.verse: 11For he will give his angels orders concerning you,

poetryblock.poem: to protect you in all your ways.

poem.verse: 12They will support you with their hands

poetryblock.poem: so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.

poem.verse: 13You will tread on the lion and the cobra;

poetryblock.poem: you will trample the young lion and the serpent.

poem.verse: 14Because he has his heart set on me,

poetryblock.poem: I will deliver him;
I will protect him because he knows my name.

poem.verse: 15When he calls out to me, I will answer him;

poetryblock.poem: I will be with him in trouble.
I will rescue him and give him honour.

poem.verse: 16I will satisfy him with a long life

poetryblock.poem: and show him my salvation.

chapter.head2: A psalm. A song for the Sabbath day.

poem.verse: 1It is good to give thanks to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: to sing praise to your name, Most High,

poem.verse: 2to declare your faithful love in the morning

poetryblock.poem: and your faithfulness at night,

poem.verse: 3with a ten-stringed harp

poetryblock.poem: and the music of a lyre.

poem.verse: 4For you have made me rejoice, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: by what you have done;
I will shout for joy
because of the works of your hands.

poem.verse: 5How magnificent are your works, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: how profound your thoughts!

poem.verse: 6A stupid person does not know,

poetryblock.poem: a fool does not understand this:

poem.verse: 7though the wicked sprout like grass

poetryblock.poem: and all evildoers flourish,
they will be eternally destroyed.

poem.verse: 8But you, Lord, are exalted for ever.
9For indeed, Lord, your enemies –

poetryblock.poem: indeed, your enemies will perish;
all evildoers will be scattered.

poem.verse: 10You have lifted up my horn

poetryblock.poem: like that of a wild ox;
I have been anointed with the finest oil.

poem.verse: 11My eyes look at my enemies;

poetryblock.poem: when evildoers rise against me,
my ears hear them.

poem.verse: 12The righteous thrive like a palm tree

poetryblock.poem: and grow like a cedar tree in Lebanon.

poem.verse: 13Planted in the house of the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: they thrive in the courts of our God.

poem.verse: 14They will still bear fruit in old age,

poetryblock.poem: healthy and green,

poem.verse: 15to declare, ‘The Lord is just;

poetryblock.poem: he is my rock,
and there is no unrighteousness in him.’

poem.verse: 1The Lord reigns! He is robed in majesty;

poetryblock.poem: the Lord is robed, enveloped in strength.
The world is firmly established;
it cannot be shaken.

poem.verse: 2Your throne has been established

poetryblock.poem: from the beginning;
you are from eternity.

poem.verse: 3The floods have lifted up, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: the floods have lifted up their voice;
the floods lift up their pounding waves.

poem.verse: 4Greater than the roar of a huge torrent –

poetryblock.poem: the mighty breakers of the sea –
the Lord on high is majestic.

poem.verse: 5Lord, your testimonies are completely reliable;

poetryblock.poem: holiness adorns your house
for all the days to come.

poem.verse: 1Lord, God of vengeance –

poetryblock.poem: God of vengeance, shine!

poem.verse: 2Rise up, Judge of the earth;

poetryblock.poem: repay the proud what they deserve.

poem.verse: 3Lord, how long will the wicked –

poetryblock.poem: how long will the wicked celebrate?

poem.verse: 4They pour out arrogant words;

poetryblock.poem: all the evildoers boast.

poem.verse: 5Lord, they crush your people;

poetryblock.poem: they oppress your heritage.

poem.verse: 6They kill the widow and the resident foreigner

poetryblock.poem: and murder the fatherless.

poem.verse: 7They say, ‘The Lord doesn’t see it.

poetryblock.poem: The God of Jacob doesn’t pay attention.’

poem.verse: 8Pay attention, you stupid people!

poetryblock.poem: Fools, when will you be wise?

poem.verse: 9Can the one who shaped the ear not hear,

poetryblock.poem: the one who formed the eye not see?

poem.verse: 10The one who instructs nations,

poetryblock.poem: the one who teaches mankind knowledge –
does he not discipline?

poem.verse: 11The Lord knows the thoughts of mankind;

poetryblock.poem: they are futile.

poem.verse: 12Lord, how happy is anyone you discipline

poetryblock.poem: and teach from your law

poem.verse: 13to give him relief from troubled times

poetryblock.poem: until a pit is dug for the wicked.

poem.verse: 14The Lord will not leave his people

poetryblock.poem: or abandon his heritage,

poem.verse: 15for the administration of justice will again be righteous,

poetryblock.poem: and all the upright in heart will follow it.

poem.verse: 16Who stands up for me against the wicked?

poetryblock.poem: Who takes a stand for me against evildoers?

poem.verse: 17If the Lord had not been my helper,

poetryblock.poem: I would soon rest in the silence of death.

poem.verse: 18If I say, ‘My foot is slipping,’

poetryblock.poem: your faithful love will support me, Lord.

poem.verse: 19When I am filled with cares,

poetryblock.poem: your comfort brings me joy.

poem.verse: 20Can a corrupt throne be your ally,

poetryblock.poem: a throne that makes evil laws?

poem.verse: 21They band together against the life of the righteous

poetryblock.poem: and condemn the innocent to death.

poem.verse: 22But the Lord is my refuge;

poetryblock.poem: my God is the rock of my protection.

poem.verse: 23He will pay them back for their sins

poetryblock.poem: and destroy them for their evil.
The Lord our God will destroy them.

poem.verse: 1Come, let’s shout joyfully to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: shout triumphantly to the rock of our salvation!

poem.verse: 2Let’s enter his presence with thanksgiving;

poetryblock.poem: let’s shout triumphantly to him in song.

poem.verse: 3For the Lord is a great God,

poetryblock.poem: a great King above all gods.

poem.verse: 4The depths of the earth are in his hand,

poetryblock.poem: and the mountain peaks are his.

poem.verse: 5The sea is his; he made it.

poetryblock.poem: His hands formed the dry land.

poem.verse: 6Come, let’s worship and bow down;

poetryblock.poem: let’s kneel before the Lord our Maker.

poem.verse: 7For he is our God,

poetryblock.poem: and we are the people of his pasture,
the sheep under his care.
Today, if you hear his voice:

poem.verse: 8Do not harden your hearts as at Meribah,

poetryblock.poem: as on that day at Massah in the wilderness

poem.verse: 9where your ancestors tested me;

poetryblock.poem: they tried me, though they had seen what I did.

poem.verse: 10For forty years I was disgusted with that generation;

poetryblock.poem: I said, ‘They are a people whose hearts go astray;
they do not know my ways.’

poem.verse: 11So I swore in my anger,

poetryblock.poem: ‘They will not enter my rest.’

poem.verse: 1Sing a new song to the Lord;

poetryblock.poem: let the whole earth sing to the Lord.

poem.verse: 2Sing to the Lord, bless his name;

poetryblock.poem: proclaim his salvation from day to day.

poem.verse: 3Declare his glory among the nations,

poetryblock.poem: his wondrous works among all peoples.

poem.verse: 4For the Lord is great and is highly praised;

poetryblock.poem: he is feared above all gods.

poem.verse: 5For all the gods of the peoples are worthless idols,

poetryblock.poem: but the Lord made the heavens.

poem.verse: 6Splendour and majesty are before him;

poetryblock.poem: strength and beauty are in his sanctuary.

poem.verse: 7Ascribe to the Lord, you families of the peoples,

poetryblock.poem: ascribe to the Lord glory and strength.

poem.verse: 8Ascribe to the Lord the glory of his name;

poetryblock.poem: bring an offering and enter his courts.

poem.verse: 9Worship the Lord in the splendour of his holiness;

poetryblock.poem: let the whole earth tremble before him.

poem.verse: 10Say among the nations, ‘The Lord reigns.

poetryblock.poem: The world is firmly established; it cannot be shaken.
He judges the peoples fairly.’

poem.verse: 11Let the heavens be glad and the earth rejoice;

poetryblock.poem: let the sea and all that fills it resound.

poem.verse: 12Let the fields and everything in them celebrate.

poetryblock.poem: Then all the trees of the forest will shout for joy

poem.verse: 13before the Lord, for he is coming –

poetryblock.poem: for he is coming to judge the earth.
He will judge the world with righteousness
and the peoples with his faithfulness.

poem.verse: 1The Lord reigns! Let the earth rejoice;

poetryblock.poem: let the many coasts and islands be glad.

poem.verse: 2Clouds and total darkness surround him;

poetryblock.poem: righteousness and justice are the foundation of his throne.

poem.verse: 3Fire goes before him

poetryblock.poem: and burns up his foes on every side.

poem.verse: 4His lightning lights up the world;

poetryblock.poem: the earth sees and trembles.

poem.verse: 5The mountains melt like wax

poetryblock.poem: at the presence of the Lord –
at the presence of the Lord of the whole earth.

poem.verse: 6The heavens proclaim his righteousness;

poetryblock.poem: all the peoples see his glory.

poem.verse: 7All who serve carved images,

poetryblock.poem: those who boast in worthless idols, will be put to shame.
All the gods must worship him.

poem.verse: 8Zion hears and is glad,

poetryblock.poem: Judah’s villages rejoice
because of your judgements, Lord.

poem.verse: 9For you, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: are the Most High over the whole earth;
you are exalted above all the gods.

poem.verse: 10You who love the Lord, hate evil!

poetryblock.poem: He protects the lives of his faithful ones;
he rescues them from the power of the wicked.

poem.verse: 11Light dawns for the righteous,

poetryblock.poem: gladness for the upright in heart.

poem.verse: 12Be glad in the Lord, you righteous ones,

poetryblock.poem: and give thanks to his holy name.

chapter.head2: A psalm.

poem.verse: 1Sing a new song to the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: for he has performed wonders;
his right hand and holy arm
have won him victory.

poem.verse: 2The Lord has made his victory known;

poetryblock.poem: he has revealed his righteousness
in the sight of the nations.

poem.verse: 3He has remembered his love

poetryblock.poem: and faithfulness to the house of Israel;
all the ends of the earth
have seen our God’s victory.

poem.verse: 4Let the whole earth shout to the Lord;

poetryblock.poem: be jubilant, shout for joy, and sing.

poem.verse: 5Sing to the Lord with the lyre,

poetryblock.poem: with the lyre and melodious song.

poem.verse: 6With trumpets and the blast of the ram’s horn

poetryblock.poem: shout triumphantly
in the presence of the Lord, our King.

poem.verse: 7Let the sea and all that fills it,

poetryblock.poem: the world and those who live in it, resound.

poem.verse: 8Let the rivers clap their hands;

poetryblock.poem: let the mountains shout together for joy

poem.verse: 9before the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: for he is coming to judge the earth.
He will judge the world righteously
and the peoples fairly.

poem.verse: 1The Lord reigns! Let the peoples tremble.

poetryblock.poem: He is enthroned between the cherubim.
Let the earth quake.

poem.verse: 2The Lord is great in Zion;

poetryblock.poem: he is exalted above all the peoples.

poem.verse: 3Let them praise your great

poetryblock.poem: and awe-inspiring name.
He is holy.

poem.verse: 4The mighty King loves justice.

poetryblock.poem: You have established fairness;
you have administered justice
and righteousness in Jacob.

poem.verse: 5Exalt the Lord our God;

poetryblock.poem: bow in worship at his footstool.
He is holy.

poem.verse: 6Moses and Aaron were among his priests;

poetryblock.poem: Samuel also was among those calling on his name.
They called to the Lord and he answered them.

poem.verse: 7He spoke to them in a pillar of cloud;

poetryblock.poem: they kept his decrees and the statutes he gave them.

poem.verse: 8Lord our God, you answered them.

poetryblock.poem: You were a forgiving God to them,
but an avenger of their sinful actions.

poem.verse: 9Exalt the Lord our God;

poetryblock.poem: bow in worship at his holy mountain,
for the Lord our God is holy.

chapter.head2: A psalm of thanksgiving.

poem.verse: 1Let the whole earth shout triumphantly to the Lord!
2Serve the Lord with gladness;

poetryblock.poem: come before him with joyful songs.

poem.verse: 3Acknowledge that the Lord is God.

poetryblock.poem: He made us, and we are his–
his people, the sheep of his pasture.

poem.verse: 4Enter his gates with thanksgiving

poetryblock.poem: and his courts with praise.
Give thanks to him and bless his name.

poem.verse: 5For the Lord is good, and his faithful love endures for ever;

poetryblock.poem: his faithfulness, through all generations.

chapter.head2: A psalm of David.

poem.verse: 1I will sing of faithful love and justice;

poetryblock.poem: I will sing praise to you, Lord.

poem.verse: 2I will pay attention to the way of integrity.

poetryblock.poem: When will you come to me?
I will live with a heart of integrity in my house.

poem.verse: 3I will not let anything worthless guide me.

poetryblock.poem: I hate the practice of transgression;
it will not cling to me.

poem.verse: 4A devious heart will be far from me;

poetryblock.poem: I will not be involved with evil.

poem.verse: 5I will destroy anyone

poetryblock.poem: who secretly slanders his neighbour;
I cannot tolerate anyone
with haughty eyes or an arrogant heart.

poem.verse: 6My eyes favour the faithful of the land

poetryblock.poem: so that they may sit down with me.
The one who follows the way of integrity
may serve me.

poem.verse: 7No one who acts deceitfully

poetryblock.poem: will live in my palace;
the one who tells lies
will not be retained here to guide me.

poem.verse: 8Every morning I will destroy

poetryblock.poem: all the wicked of the land,
wiping out all evildoers from the Lord’s city.

chapter.head2: A prayer of a suffering person who is weak and pours out his lament before the Lord.

poem.verse: 1Lord, hear my prayer;

poetryblock.poem: let my cry for help come before you.

poem.verse: 2Do not hide your face from me in my day of trouble.

poetryblock.poem: Listen closely to me;
answer me quickly when I call.

poem.verse: 3For my days vanish like smoke,

poetryblock.poem: and my bones burn like a furnace.

poem.verse: 4My heart is suffering, withered like grass;

poetryblock.poem: I even forget to eat my food.

poem.verse: 5Because of the sound of my groaning,

poetryblock.poem: my flesh sticks to my bones.

poem.verse: 6I am like an eagle owl,

poetryblock.poem: like a little owl among the ruins.

poem.verse: 7I stay awake;

poetryblock.poem: I am like a solitary bird on a roof.

poem.verse: 8My enemies taunt me all day long;

poetryblock.poem: they ridicule and use my name as a curse.

poem.verse: 9I eat ashes like bread

poetryblock.poem: and mingle my drinks with tears

poem.verse: 10because of your indignation and wrath;

poetryblock.poem: for you have picked me up and thrown me aside.

poem.verse: 11My days are like a lengthening shadow,

poetryblock.poem: and I wither away like grass.

poem.verse: 12But you, Lord, are enthroned for ever;

poetryblock.poem: your fame endures to all generations.

poem.verse: 13You will rise up and have compassion on Zion,

poetryblock.poem: for it is time to show favour to her –
the appointed time has come.

poem.verse: 14For your servants take delight in its stones

poetryblock.poem: and favour its dust.

poem.verse: 15Then the nations will fear the name of the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and all the kings of the earth your glory,

poem.verse: 16for the Lord will rebuild Zion;

poetryblock.poem: he will appear in his glory.

poem.verse: 17He will pay attention to the prayer of the destitute

poetryblock.poem: and will not despise their prayer.

poem.verse: 18This will be written for a later generation,

poetryblock.poem: and a people who have not yet been created will praise the Lord:

poem.verse: 19He looked down from his holy heights –

poetryblock.poem: the Lord gazed out from heaven to earth –

poem.verse: 20to hear a prisoner’s groaning,

poetryblock.poem: to set free those condemned to die,

poem.verse: 21so that they might declare

poetryblock.poem: the name of the Lord in Zion
and his praise in Jerusalem

poem.verse: 22when peoples and kingdoms are assembled

poetryblock.poem: to serve the Lord.

poem.verse: 23He has broken my strength in midcourse;

poetryblock.poem: he has shortened my days.

poem.verse: 24I say, ‘My God, do not take me

poetryblock.poem: in the middle of my life!
Your years continue through all generations.

poem.verse: 25Long ago you established the earth,

poetryblock.poem: and the heavens are the work of your hands.

poem.verse: 26They will perish, but you will endure;

poetryblock.poem: all of them will wear out like clothing.
You will change them like a garment,
and they will pass away.

poem.verse: 27But you are the same,

poetryblock.poem: and your years will never end.

poem.verse: 28Your servants’ children will dwell securely,

poetryblock.poem: and their offspring will be established before you.’

chapter.head2: Of David.

poem.verse: 1My soul, bless the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and all that is within me, bless his holy name.

poem.verse: 2My soul, bless the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and do not forget all his benefits.

poem.verse: 3He forgives all your iniquity;

poetryblock.poem: he heals all your diseases.

poem.verse: 4He redeems your life from the Pit;

poetryblock.poem: he crowns you with faithful love and compassion.

poem.verse: 5He satisfies you with good things;

poetryblock.poem: your youth is renewed like the eagle.

poem.verse: 6The Lord executes acts of righteousness

poetryblock.poem: and justice for all the oppressed.

poem.verse: 7He revealed his ways to Moses,

poetryblock.poem: his deeds to the people of Israel.

poem.verse: 8The Lord is compassionate and gracious,

poetryblock.poem: slow to anger and abounding in faithful love.

poem.verse: 9He will not always accuse us

poetryblock.poem: or be angry for ever.

poem.verse: 10He has not dealt with us as our sins deserve

poetryblock.poem: or repaid us according to our iniquities.

poem.verse: 11For as high as the heavens are above the earth,

poetryblock.poem: so great is his faithful love
towards those who fear him.

poem.verse: 12As far as the east is from the west,

poetryblock.poem: so far has he removed
our transgressions from us.

poem.verse: 13As a father has compassion on his children,

poetryblock.poem: so the Lord has compassion on those who fear him.

poem.verse: 14For he knows what we are made of,

poetryblock.poem: remembering that we are dust.

poem.verse: 15As for man, his days are like grass –

poetryblock.poem: he blooms like a flower of the field;

poem.verse: 16when the wind passes over it, it vanishes,

poetryblock.poem: and its place is no longer known.

poem.verse: 17But from eternity to eternity

poetryblock.poem: the Lord’s faithful love is towards those who fear him,
and his righteousness towards the grandchildren

poem.verse: 18of those who keep his covenant,

poetryblock.poem: who remember to observe his precepts.

poem.verse: 19The Lord has established his throne in heaven,

poetryblock.poem: and his kingdom rules over all.

poem.verse: 20Bless the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: all his angels of great strength,
who do his word,
obedient to his command.

poem.verse: 21Bless the Lord, all his armies,

poetryblock.poem: his servants who do his will.

poem.verse: 22Bless the Lord, all his works

poetryblock.poem: in all the places where he rules.
My soul, bless the Lord!

poem.verse: 1My soul, bless the Lord!

poetryblock.poem: Lord my God, you are very great;
you are clothed with majesty and splendour.

poem.verse: 2He wraps himself in light as if it were a robe,

poetryblock.poem: spreading out the sky like a canopy,

poem.verse: 3laying the beams of his palace

poetryblock.poem: on the waters above,
making the clouds his chariot,
walking on the wings of the wind,

poem.verse: 4and making the winds his messengers,

poetryblock.poem: flames of fire his servants.

poem.verse: 5He established the earth on its foundations;

poetryblock.poem: it will never be shaken.

poem.verse: 6You covered it with the deep

poetryblock.poem: as if it were a garment;
the water stood above the mountains.

poem.verse: 7At your rebuke the water fled;

poetryblock.poem: at the sound of your thunder they hurried away –

poem.verse: 8mountains rose and valleys sank –

poetryblock.poem: to the place you established for them.

poem.verse: 9You set a boundary they cannot cross;

poetryblock.poem: they will never cover the earth again.

poem.verse: 10He causes the springs to gush into the valleys;

poetryblock.poem: they flow between the mountains.

poem.verse: 11They supply water for every wild beast;

poetryblock.poem: the wild donkeys quench their thirst.

poem.verse: 12The birds of the sky live beside the springs;

poetryblock.poem: they make their voices heard among the foliage.

poem.verse: 13He waters the mountains from his palace;

poetryblock.poem: the earth is satisfied by the fruit of your labour.

poem.verse: 14He causes grass to grow for the livestock

poetryblock.poem: and provides crops for man to cultivate,
producing food from the earth,

poem.verse: 15wine that makes human hearts glad –

poetryblock.poem: making his face shine with oil –
and bread that sustains human hearts.

poem.verse: 16The trees of the Lord flourish,

poetryblock.poem: the cedars of Lebanon that he planted.

poem.verse: 17There the birds make their nests;

poetryblock.poem: storks make their homes in the pine trees.

poem.verse: 18The high mountains are for the wild goats;

poetryblock.poem: the cliffs are a refuge for hyraxes.

poem.verse: 19He made the moon to mark the festivals;

poetryblock.poem: the sun knows when to set.

poem.verse: 20You bring darkness, and it becomes night,

poetryblock.poem: when all the forest animals stir.

poem.verse: 21The young lions roar for their prey

poetryblock.poem: and seek their food from God.

poem.verse: 22The sun rises; they go back

poetryblock.poem: and lie down in their dens.

poem.verse: 23Man goes out to his work

poetryblock.poem: and to his labour until evening.

poem.verse: 24How countless are your works, Lord!

poetryblock.poem: In wisdom you have made them all;
the earth is full of your creatures.

poem.verse: 25Here is the sea, vast and wide,

poetryblock.poem: teeming with creatures beyond number –
living things both large and small.

poem.verse: 26There the ships move about,

poetryblock.poem: and Leviathan, which you formed to play there.

poem.verse: 27All of them wait for you

poetryblock.poem: to give them their food at the right time.

poem.verse: 28When you give it to them,

poetryblock.poem: they gather it;
when you open your hand,
they are satisfied with good things.

poem.verse: 29When you hide your face,

poetryblock.poem: they are terrified;
when you take away their breath,
they die and return to the dust.

poem.verse: 30When you send your breath,

poetryblock.poem: they are created,
and you renew the surface of the ground.

poem.verse: 31May the glory of the Lord endure for ever;

poetryblock.poem: may the Lord rejoice in his works.

poem.verse: 32He looks at the earth, and it trembles;

poetryblock.poem: he touches the mountains,
and they pour out smoke.

poem.verse: 33I will sing to the Lord all my life;

poetryblock.poem: I will sing praise to my God while I live.

poem.verse: 34May my meditation be pleasing to him;

poetryblock.poem: I will rejoice in the Lord.

poem.verse: 35May sinners vanish from the earth

poetryblock.poem: and wicked people be no more.
My soul, bless the Lord!
Hallelujah!

poem.verse: 1Give thanks to the Lord, call on his name;

poetryblock.poem: proclaim his deeds among the peoples.

poem.verse: 2Sing to him, sing praise to him;

poetryblock.poem: tell about all his wondrous works!

poem.verse: 3Boast in his holy name;

poetryblock.poem: let the hearts of those who seek the Lord rejoice.

poem.verse: 4Seek the Lord and his strength;

poetryblock.poem: seek his face always.

poem.verse: 5Remember the wondrous works he has done,

poetryblock.poem: his wonders, and the judgements he has pronounced,

poem.verse: 6you offspring of Abraham his servant,

poetryblock.poem: Jacob’s descendants ​– ​his chosen ones.

poem.verse: 7He is the Lord our God;

poetryblock.poem: his judgements govern the whole earth.

poem.verse: 8He remembers his covenant for ever,

poetryblock.poem: the promise he ordained
for a thousand generations –

poem.verse: 9the covenant he made with Abraham,

poetryblock.poem: swore to Isaac,

poem.verse: 10and confirmed to Jacob as a decree

poetryblock.poem: and to Israel as a permanent covenant:

poem.verse: 11‘I will give the land of Canaan to you

poetryblock.poem: as your inherited portion.’

poem.verse: 12When they were few in number,

poetryblock.poem: very few indeed,
and resident foreigners in Canaan,

poem.verse: 13wandering from nation to nation

poetryblock.poem: and from one kingdom to another,

poem.verse: 14he allowed no one to oppress them;

poetryblock.poem: he rebuked kings on their behalf:

poem.verse: 15‘Do not touch my anointed ones,

poetryblock.poem: or harm my prophets.’

poem.verse: 16He called down famine against the land

poetryblock.poem: and destroyed the entire food supply.

poem.verse: 17He had sent a man ahead of them –

poetryblock.poem: Joseph, who was sold as a slave.

poem.verse: 18They hurt his feet with shackles;

poetryblock.poem: his neck was put in an iron collar.

poem.verse: 19Until the time his prediction came true,

poetryblock.poem: the word of the Lord tested him.

poem.verse: 20The king sent for him and released him;

poetryblock.poem: the ruler of peoples set him free.

poem.verse: 21He made him master of his household,

poetryblock.poem: ruler over all his possessions –

poem.verse: 22binding his officials at will

poetryblock.poem: and instructing his elders.

poem.verse: 23Then Israel went to Egypt;

poetryblock.poem: Jacob lived as a foreigner in the land of Ham.

poem.verse: 24The Lord made his people very fruitful;

poetryblock.poem: he made them more numerous than their foes,

poem.verse: 25whose hearts he turned to hate his people

poetryblock.poem: and to deal deceptively with his servants.

poem.verse: 26He sent Moses his servant,

poetryblock.poem: and Aaron, whom he had chosen.

poem.verse: 27They performed his miraculous signs among them

poetryblock.poem: and wonders in the land of Ham.

poem.verse: 28He sent darkness, and it became dark –

poetryblock.poem: for did they not defy his commands?

poem.verse: 29He turned their water into blood

poetryblock.poem: and caused their fish to die.

poem.verse: 30Their land was overrun with frogs,

poetryblock.poem: even in their royal chambers.

poem.verse: 31He spoke, and insects came –

poetryblock.poem: gnats throughout their country.

poem.verse: 32He gave them hail for rain,

poetryblock.poem: and lightning throughout their land.

poem.verse: 33He struck their vines and fig trees

poetryblock.poem: and shattered the trees of their territory.

poem.verse: 34He spoke, and locusts came –

poetryblock.poem: young locusts without number.

poem.verse: 35They devoured all the vegetation in their land

poetryblock.poem: and consumed the produce of their land.

poem.verse: 36He struck all the firstborn in their land,

poetryblock.poem: all their first progeny.

poem.verse: 37Then he brought Israel out with silver and gold,

poetryblock.poem: and no one among his tribes stumbled.

poem.verse: 38Egypt was glad when they left,

poetryblock.poem: for the dread of Israel had fallen on them.

poem.verse: 39He spread a cloud as a covering

poetryblock.poem: and gave a fire to light up the night.

poem.verse: 40They asked, and he brought quail

poetryblock.poem: and satisfied them with bread from heaven.

poem.verse: 41He opened a rock, and water gushed out;

poetryblock.poem: it flowed like a stream in the desert.

poem.verse: 42For he remembered his holy promise

poetryblock.poem: to Abraham his servant.

poem.verse: 43He brought his people out with rejoicing,

poetryblock.poem: his chosen ones with shouts of joy.

poem.verse: 44He gave them the lands of the nations,

poetryblock.poem: and they inherited
what other peoples had worked for.

poem.verse: 45All this happened

poetryblock.poem: so that they might keep his statutes
and obey his instructions.
Hallelujah!

poem.verse: 1Hallelujah!

poetryblock.poem: Give thanks to the Lord, for he is good;
his faithful love endures for ever.

poem.verse: 2Who can declare the Lord’s mighty acts

poetryblock.poem: or proclaim all the praise due him?

poem.verse: 3How happy are those who uphold justice,

poetryblock.poem: who practise righteousness at all times.

poem.verse: 4Remember me, Lord,

poetryblock.poem: when you show favour to your people.
Come to me with your salvation

poem.verse: 5so that I may enjoy the prosperity

poetryblock.poem: of your chosen ones,
rejoice in the joy of your nation,
and boast about your heritage.

poem.verse: 6Both we and our ancestors have sinned;

poetryblock.poem: we have done wrong and have acted wickedly.

poem.verse: 7Our ancestors in Egypt did not grasp

poetryblock.poem: the significance of your wondrous works
or remember your many acts of faithful love;
instead, they rebelled by the sea ​– ​the Red Sea.

poem.verse: 8Yet he saved them for his name’s sake,

poetryblock.poem: to make his power known.

poem.verse: 9He rebuked the Red Sea, and it dried up;

poetryblock.poem: he led them through the depths as through a desert.

poem.verse: 10He saved them from the power of the adversary;

poetryblock.poem: he redeemed them from the power of the enemy.

poem.verse: 11Water covered their foes;

poetryblock.poem: not one of them remained.

poem.verse: 12Then they believed his promises

poetryblock.poem: and sang his praise.

poem.verse: 13They soon forgot his works

poetryblock.poem: and would not wait for his counsel.

poem.verse: 14They were seized with craving in the wilderness

poetryblock.poem: and tested God in the desert.

poem.verse: 15He gave them what they asked for,

poetryblock.poem: but sent a wasting disease among them.

poem.verse: 16In the camp they were envious of Moses

poetryblock.poem: and of Aaron, the Lord’s holy one.

poem.verse: 17The earth opened up and swallowed Dathan;

poetryblock.poem: it covered the assembly of Abiram.

poem.verse: 18Fire blazed throughout their assembly;

poetryblock.poem: flames consumed the wicked.

poem.verse: 19At Horeb they made a calf

poetryblock.poem: and worshipped the cast metal image.

poem.verse: 20They exchanged their glory

poetryblock.poem: for the image of a grass-eating ox.

poem.verse: 21They forgot God their Saviour,

poetryblock.poem: who did great things in Egypt,

poem.verse: 22wondrous works in the land of Ham,

poetryblock.poem: awe-inspiring acts at the Red Sea.

poem.verse: 23So he said he would have destroyed them –

poetryblock.poem: if Moses his chosen one
had not stood before him in the breach
to turn his wrath away from destroying them.

poem.verse: 24They despised the pleasant land

poetryblock.poem: and did not believe his promise.

poem.verse: 25They grumbled in their tents

poetryblock.poem: and did not listen to the Lord.

poem.verse: 26So he raised his hand against them with an oath

poetryblock.poem: that he would make them fall in the desert

poem.verse: 27and would disperse their descendants

poetryblock.poem: among the nations,
scattering them throughout the lands.

poem.verse: 28They aligned themselves with Baal of Peor

poetryblock.poem: and ate sacrifices offered to lifeless gods.

poem.verse: 29They angered the Lord with their deeds,

poetryblock.poem: and a plague broke out against them.

poem.verse: 30But Phinehas stood up and intervened,

poetryblock.poem: and the plague was stopped.

poem.verse: 31It was credited to him as righteousness

poetryblock.poem: throughout all generations to come.

poem.verse: 32They angered the Lord at the Waters of Meribah,

poetryblock.poem: and Moses suffered because of them,

poem.verse: 33for they embittered his spirit,

poetryblock.poem: and he spoke rashly with his lips.

poem.verse: 34They did not destroy the peoples

poetryblock.poem: as the Lord had commanded them

poem.verse: 35but mingled with the nations

poetryblock.poem: and adopted their ways.

poem.verse: 36They served their idols,

poetryblock.poem: which became a snare to them.

poem.verse: 37They sacrificed their sons and daughters to demons.
38They shed innocent blood –

poetryblock.poem: the blood of their sons and daughters
whom they sacrificed to the idols of Canaan;
so the land became polluted with blood.

poem.verse: 39They defiled themselves by their actions

poetryblock.poem: and prostituted themselves by their deeds.

poem.verse: 40Therefore the Lord’s anger burned against his people,

poetryblock.poem: and he abhorred his own inheritance.

poem.verse: 41He handed them over to the nations;

poetryblock.poem: those who hated them ruled over them.

poem.verse: 42Their enemies oppressed them,

poetryblock.poem: and they were subdued under their power.

poem.verse: 43He rescued them many times,

poetryblock.poem: but they continued to rebel deliberately
and were beaten down by their iniquity.

poem.verse: 44When he heard their cry,

poetryblock.poem: he took note of their distress,

poem.verse: 45remembered his covenant with them,

poetryblock.poem: and relented according to the abundance
of his faithful love.

poem.verse: 46He caused them to be pitied

poetryblock.poem: before all their captors.

poem.verse: 47Save us, Lord our God,

poetryblock.poem: and gather us from the nations,
so that we may give thanks to your holy name
and rejoice in your praise.

poem.verse: 48Blessed be the Lord God of Israel,

poetryblock.poem: from everlasting to everlasting.
Let all the people say, ‘Amen! ’
Hallelujah!

poem.verse: 1Give thanks to the Lord, for he is good;

poetryblock.poem: his faithful love endures for ever.

poem.verse: 2Let the redeemed of the Lord proclaim

poetryblock.poem: that he has redeemed them from the power of the foe

poem.verse: 3and has gathered them from the lands –

poetryblock.poem: from the east and the west,
from the north and the south.

poem.verse: 4Some wandered in the desolate wilderness,

poetryblock.poem: finding no way to a city where they could live.

poem.verse: 5They were hungry and thirsty;

poetryblock.poem: their spirits failed within them.

poem.verse: 6Then they cried out to the Lord in their trouble;

poetryblock.poem: he rescued them from their distress.

poem.verse: 7He led them by the right path

poetryblock.poem: to go to a city where they could live.

poem.verse: 8Let them give thanks to the Lord

poetryblock.poem: for his faithful love
and his wondrous works for all humanity.

poem.verse: 9For he has satisfied the thirsty

poetryblock.poem: and filled the hungry with good things.

poem.verse: 10Others sat in darkness and gloom –

poetryblock.poem: prisoners in cruel chains –

poem.verse: 11because they rebelled against God’s commands

poetryblock.poem: and despised the counsel of the Most High.

poem.verse: 12He broke their spirits with hard labour;

poetryblock.poem: they stumbled, and there was no one to help.

poem.verse: 13Then they cried out to the Lord in their trouble;

poetryblock.poem: he saved them from their distress.

poem.verse: 14He brought them out of darkness and gloom

poetryblock.poem: and broke their chains apart.

poem.verse: 15Let them give thanks to the Lord

poetryblock.poem: for his faithful love
and his wondrous works for all humanity.

poem.verse: 16For he has broken down the bronze gates

poetryblock.poem: and cut through the iron bars.

poem.verse: 17Fools suffered affliction

poetryblock.poem: because of their rebellious ways and their iniquities.

poem.verse: 18They loathed all food

poetryblock.poem: and came near the gates of death.

poem.verse: 19Then they cried out to the Lord in their trouble;

poetryblock.poem: he saved them from their distress.

poem.verse: 20He sent his word and healed them;

poetryblock.poem: he rescued them from their traps.

poem.verse: 21Let them give thanks to the Lord

poetryblock.poem: for his faithful love
and his wondrous works for all humanity.

poem.verse: 22Let them offer thanksgiving sacrifices

poetryblock.poem: and announce his works with shouts of joy.

poem.verse: 23Others went to sea in ships,

poetryblock.poem: conducting trade on the vast water.

poem.verse: 24They saw the Lord’s works,

poetryblock.poem: his wondrous works in the deep.

poem.verse: 25He spoke and raised a stormy wind

poetryblock.poem: that stirred up the waves of the sea.

poem.verse: 26Rising up to the sky, sinking down to the depths,

poetryblock.poem: their courage melting away in anguish,

poem.verse: 27they reeled and staggered like a drunkard,

poetryblock.poem: and all their skill was useless.

poem.verse: 28Then they cried out to the Lord in their trouble,

poetryblock.poem: and he brought them out of their distress.

poem.verse: 29He stilled the storm to a whisper,

poetryblock.poem: and the waves of the sea were hushed.

poem.verse: 30They rejoiced when the waves grew quiet.

poetryblock.poem: Then he guided them to the harbour they longed for.

poem.verse: 31Let them give thanks to the Lord

poetryblock.poem: for his faithful love
and his wondrous works for all humanity.

poem.verse: 32Let them exalt him in the assembly of the people

poetryblock.poem: and praise him in the council of the elders.

poem.verse: 33He turns rivers into desert,

poetryblock.poem: springs into thirsty ground,

poem.verse: 34and fruitful land into salty wasteland,

poetryblock.poem: because of the wickedness of its inhabitants.

poem.verse: 35He turns a desert into a pool,

poetryblock.poem: dry land into springs.

poem.verse: 36He causes the hungry to settle there,

poetryblock.poem: and they establish a city where they can live.

poem.verse: 37They sow fields and plant vineyards

poetryblock.poem: that yield a fruitful harvest.

poem.verse: 38He blesses them, and they multiply greatly;

poetryblock.poem: he does not let their livestock decrease.

poem.verse: 39When they are diminished and are humbled

poetryblock.poem: by cruel oppression and sorrow,

poem.verse: 40he pours contempt on nobles

poetryblock.poem: and makes them wander in a trackless wasteland.

poem.verse: 41But he lifts the needy out of their suffering

poetryblock.poem: and makes their families multiply like flocks.

poem.verse: 42The upright see it and rejoice,

poetryblock.poem: and all injustice shuts its mouth.

poem.verse: 43Let whoever is wise pay attention to these things

poetryblock.poem: and consider the Lord’s acts of faithful love.

chapter.head2: A song. A psalm of David.

poem.verse: 1My heart is confident, God;

poetryblock.poem: I will sing; I will sing praises
with the whole of my being.

poem.verse: 2Wake up, harp and lyre!

poetryblock.poem: I will wake up the dawn.

poem.verse: 3I will praise you, Lord, among the peoples;

poetryblock.poem: I will sing praises to you among the nations.

poem.verse: 4For your faithful love is higher than the heavens,

poetryblock.poem: and your faithfulness reaches to the clouds.

poem.verse: 5God, be exalted above the heavens,

poetryblock.poem: and let your glory be over the whole earth.

poem.verse: 6Save with your right hand and answer me

poetryblock.poem: so that those you love may be rescued.

poem.verse: 7God has spoken in his sanctuary:

poetryblock.poem: ‘I will celebrate!
I will divide up Shechem.
I will apportion the Valley of Succoth.

poem.verse: 8Gilead is mine, Manasseh is mine,

poetryblock.poem: and Ephraim is my helmet;
Judah is my sceptre.

poem.verse: 9Moab is my washbasin;

poetryblock.poem: I throw my sandal on Edom.
I shout in triumph over Philistia.’

poem.verse: 10Who will bring me to the fortified city?

poetryblock.poem: Who will lead me to Edom?

poem.verse: 11God, haven’t you rejected us?

poetryblock.poem: God, you do not march out with our armies.

poem.verse: 12Give us aid against the foe,

poetryblock.poem: for human help is worthless.

poem.verse: 13With God we will perform valiantly;

poetryblock.poem: he will trample our foes.

chapter.head2: For the choir director. A psalm of David.

poem.verse: 1God of my praise, do not be silent.
2For wicked and deceitful mouths open against me;

poetryblock.poem: they speak against me with lying tongues.

poem.verse: 3They surround me with hateful words

poetryblock.poem: and attack me without cause.

poem.verse: 4In return for my love they accuse me,

poetryblock.poem: but I continue to pray.

poem.verse: 5They repay me evil for good,

poetryblock.poem: and hatred for my love.

poem.verse: 6Set a wicked person over him;

poetryblock.poem: let an accuser stand at his right hand.

poem.verse: 7When he is judged, let him be found guilty,

poetryblock.poem: and let his prayer be counted as sin.

poem.verse: 8Let his days be few;

poetryblock.poem: let another take over his position.

poem.verse: 9Let his children be fatherless

poetryblock.poem: and his wife a widow.

poem.verse: 10Let his children wander as beggars,

poetryblock.poem: searching for food far from their demolished homes.

poem.verse: 11Let a creditor seize all he has;

poetryblock.poem: let strangers plunder what he has worked for.

poem.verse: 12Let no one show him kindness,

poetryblock.poem: and let no one be gracious to his fatherless children.

poem.verse: 13Let the line of his descendants be cut off;

poetryblock.poem: let their name be blotted out in the next generation.

poem.verse: 14Let the iniquity of his fathers

poetryblock.poem: be remembered before the Lord,
and do not let his mother’s sin be blotted out.

poem.verse: 15Let their sins always remain before the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: and let him remove all memory of them from the earth.

poem.verse: 16For he did not think to show kindness,

poetryblock.poem: but pursued the suffering, needy, and broken-hearted
in order to put them to death.

poem.verse: 17He loved cursing ​– ​let it fall on him;

poetryblock.poem: he took no delight in blessing ​– ​let it be far from him.

poem.verse: 18He wore cursing like his coat –

poetryblock.poem: let it enter his body like water
and go into his bones like oil.

poem.verse: 19Let it be like a robe he wraps round himself,

poetryblock.poem: like a belt he always wears.

poem.verse: 20Let this be the Lord’s payment to my accusers,

poetryblock.poem: to those who speak evil against me.

poem.verse: 21But you, Lord, my Lord,

poetryblock.poem: deal kindly with me for your name’s sake;
because your faithful love is good, rescue me.

poem.verse: 22For I am suffering and needy;

poetryblock.poem: my heart is wounded within me.

poem.verse: 23I fade away like a lengthening shadow;

poetryblock.poem: I am shaken off like a locust.

poem.verse: 24My knees are weak from fasting,

poetryblock.poem: and my body is emaciated.

poem.verse: 25I have become an object of ridicule to my accusers;

poetryblock.poem: when they see me, they shake their heads in scorn.

poem.verse: 26Help me, Lord my God;

poetryblock.poem: save me according to your faithful love

poem.verse: 27so they may know that this is your hand

poetryblock.poem: and that you, Lord, have done it.

poem.verse: 28Though they curse, you will bless.

poetryblock.poem: When they rise up, they will be put to shame,
but your servant will rejoice.

poem.verse: 29My accusers will be clothed with disgrace;

poetryblock.poem: they will wear their shame like a cloak.

poem.verse: 30I will fervently thank the Lord with my mouth;

poetryblock.poem: I will praise him in the presence of many.

poem.verse: 31For he stands at the right hand of the needy

poetryblock.poem: to save him from those who would condemn him.

chapter.head2: A psalm of David.

poem.verse: 1This is the declaration of the Lord

poetryblock.poem: to my Lord:
‘Sit at my right hand
until I make your enemies your footstool.’

poem.verse: 2The Lord will extend your mighty sceptre from Zion.

poetryblock.poem: Rule over your surrounding enemies.

poem.verse: 3Your people will volunteer

poetryblock.poem: on your day of battle.
In holy splendour, from the womb of the dawn,
the dew of your youth belongs to you.

poem.verse: 4The Lord has sworn an oath and will not take it back:

poetryblock.poem: ‘You are a priest for ever
according to the pattern of Melchizedek.’

poem.verse: 5The Lord is at your right hand;

poetryblock.poem: he will crush kings on the day of his anger.

poem.verse: 6He will judge the nations, heaping up corpses;

poetryblock.poem: he will crush leaders over the entire world.

poem.verse: 7He will drink from the brook by the road;

poetryblock.poem: therefore, he will lift up his head.

poem.verse: 1Hallelujah!

poetryblock.poem: I will praise the Lord with all my heart
in the assembly of the upright and in the congregation.

poem.verse: 2The Lord’s works are great,

poetryblock.poem: studied by all who delight in them.

poem.verse: 3All that he does is splendid and majestic;

poetryblock.poem: his righteousness endures for ever.

poem.verse: 4He has caused his wondrous works to be remembered.

poetryblock.poem: The Lord is gracious and compassionate.

poem.verse: 5He has provided food for those who fear him;

poetryblock.poem: he remembers his covenant for ever.

poem.verse: 6He has shown his people the power of his works

poetryblock.poem: by giving them the inheritance of the nations.

poem.verse: 7The works of his hands are truth and justice;

poetryblock.poem: all his instructions are trustworthy.

poem.verse: 8They are established for ever and ever,

poetryblock.poem: enacted in truth and in uprightness.

poem.verse: 9He has sent redemption to his people.

poetryblock.poem: He has ordained his covenant for ever.
His name is holy and awe-inspiring.

poem.verse: 10The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom;

poetryblock.poem: all who follow his instructions have good insight.
His praise endures for ever.

poem.verse: 1Hallelujah!

poetryblock.poem: Happy is the person who fears the Lord,
taking great delight in his commands.

poem.verse: 2His descendants will be powerful in the land;

poetryblock.poem: the generation of the upright will be blessed.

poem.verse: 3Wealth and riches are in his house,

poetryblock.poem: and his righteousness endures for ever.

poem.verse: 4Light shines in the darkness for the upright.

poetryblock.poem: He is gracious, compassionate, and righteous.

poem.verse: 5Good will come to the one who lends generously

poetryblock.poem: and conducts his business fairly.

poem.verse: 6He will never be shaken.

poetryblock.poem: The righteous one will be remembered for ever.

poem.verse: 7He will not fear bad news;

poetryblock.poem: his heart is confident, trusting in the Lord.

poem.verse: 8His heart is assured; he will not fear.

poetryblock.poem: In the end he will look in triumph on his foes.

poem.verse: 9He distributes freely to the poor;

poetryblock.poem: his righteousness endures for ever.
His horn will be exalted in honour.

poem.verse: 10The wicked one will see it and be angry;

poetryblock.poem: he will gnash his teeth in despair.
The desire of the wicked leads to ruin.

poem.verse: 1Hallelujah!

poetryblock.poem: Give praise, servants of the Lord;
praise the name of the Lord.

poem.verse: 2Let the name of the Lord be blessed

poetryblock.poem: both now and for ever.

poem.verse: 3From the rising of the sun to its setting,

poetryblock.poem: let the name of the Lord be praised.

poem.verse: 4The Lord is exalted above all the nations,

poetryblock.poem: his glory above the heavens.

poem.verse: 5Who is like the Lord our God –

poetryblock.poem: the one enthroned on high,

poem.verse: 6who stoops down to look

poetryblock.poem: on the heavens and the earth?

poem.verse: 7He raises the poor from the dust

poetryblock.poem: and lifts the needy from the rubbish heap

poem.verse: 8in order to seat them with nobles –

poetryblock.poem: with the nobles of his people.

poem.verse: 9He gives the childless woman a household,

poetryblock.poem: making her the joyful mother of children.
Hallelujah!

poem.verse: 1When Israel came out of Egypt –

poetryblock.poem: the house of Jacob from a people
who spoke a foreign language –

poem.verse: 2Judah became his sanctuary,

poetryblock.poem: Israel, his dominion.

poem.verse: 3The sea looked and fled;

poetryblock.poem: the Jordan turned back.

poem.verse: 4The mountains skipped like rams,

poetryblock.poem: the hills, like lambs.

poem.verse: 5Why was it, sea, that you fled?

poetryblock.poem: Jordan, that you turned back?

poem.verse: 6Mountains, that you skipped like rams?

poetryblock.poem: Hills, like lambs?

poem.verse: 7Tremble, earth, at the presence of the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: at the presence of the God of Jacob,

poem.verse: 8who turned the rock into a pool,

poetryblock.poem: the flint into a spring.

poem.verse: 1Not to us, Lord, not to us,

poetryblock.poem: but to your name give glory
because of your faithful love, because of your truth.

poem.verse: 2Why should the nations say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Where is their God? ’

poem.verse: 3Our God is in heaven

poetryblock.poem: and does whatever he pleases.

poem.verse: 4Their idols are silver and gold,

poetryblock.poem: made by human hands.

poem.verse: 5They have mouths but cannot speak,

poetryblock.poem: eyes, but cannot see.

poem.verse: 6They have ears but cannot hear,

poetryblock.poem: noses, but cannot smell.

poem.verse: 7They have hands but cannot feel,

poetryblock.poem: feet, but cannot walk.
They cannot make a sound with their throats.

poem.verse: 8Those who make them are just like them,

poetryblock.poem: as are all who trust in them.

poem.verse: 9Israel, trust in the Lord!

poetryblock.poem: He is their help and shield.

poem.verse: 10House of Aaron, trust in the Lord!

poetryblock.poem: He is their help and shield.

poem.verse: 11You who fear the Lord, trust in the Lord!

poetryblock.poem: He is their help and shield.

poem.verse: 12The Lord remembers us and will bless us.

poetryblock.poem: He will bless the house of Israel;
he will bless the house of Aaron;

poem.verse: 13he will bless those who fear the Lord –

poetryblock.poem: small and great alike.

poem.verse: 14May the Lord add to your numbers,

poetryblock.poem: both yours and your children’s.

poem.verse: 15May you be blessed by the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: the Maker of heaven and earth.

poem.verse: 16The heavens are the Lord’s,

poetryblock.poem: but the earth he has given to the human race.

poem.verse: 17It is not the dead who praise the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: nor any of those descending into the silence of death.

poem.verse: 18But we will bless the Lord,

poetryblock.poem: both now and for ever.
Hallelujah!

poem.verse: 1I love the Lord because he has heard

poetryblock.poem: my appeal for mercy.

poem.verse: 2Because he has turned his ear to me,

poetryblock.poem: I will call out to him as long as I live.

poem.verse: 3The ropes of death were wrapped round me,

poetryblock.poem: and the torments of Sheol overcame me;
I encountered trouble and sorrow.

poem.verse: 4Then I called on the name of the Lord:

poetryblock.poem: ‘Lord, save me! ’

poem.verse: 5The Lord is gracious and righteous;

poetryblock.poem: our God is compassionate.

poem.verse: 6The Lord guards the inexperienced;

poetryblock.poem: I was helpless, and he saved me.

poem.verse: 7Return to your rest, my soul,

poetryblock.poem: for the Lord has been good to you.

poem.verse: 8For you, Lord, rescued me from death,

poetryblock.poem: my eyes from tears,
my feet from stumbling.

poem.verse: 9I will walk before the Lord

poetryblock.poem: in the land of the living.

poem.verse: 10I believed, even when I said,

poetryblock.poem: ‘I am severely oppressed.’

poem.verse: 11In my alarm I said,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Everyone is a liar.’

poem.verse: 12How can I repay the Lord

poetryblock.poem: for all the good he has done for me?

poem.verse: 13I will take the cup of salvation

poetryblock.poem: and call on the name of the Lord.

poem.verse: 14I will fulfil my vows to the Lord

poetryblock.poem: in the presence of all his people.

poem.verse: 15The death of his faithful ones

poetryblock.poem: is valuable in the Lord’s sight.

poem.verse: 16Lord, I am indeed your servant;

poetryblock.poem: I am your servant, the son of your female servant.
You have loosened my bonds.

poem.verse: 17I will offer you a thanksgiving sacrifice

poetryblock.poem: and call on the name of the Lord.

poem.verse: 18I will fulfil my vows to the Lord

poetryblock.poem: in the presence of all his people,

poem.verse: 19in the courts of the Lord’s house –

poetryblock.poem: within you, Jerusalem.
Hallelujah!

poem.verse: 1Praise the Lord, all nations!

poetryblock.poem: Glorify him, all peoples!

poem.verse: 2For his faithful love to us is great;

poetryblock.poem: the Lord’s faithfulness endures for ever.
Hallelujah!

poem.verse: 1Give thanks to the Lord, for he is good;

poetryblock.poem: his faithful love endures for ever.

poem.verse: 2Let Israel say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘His faithful love endures for ever.’

poem.verse: 3Let the house of Aaron say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘His faithful love endures for ever.’

poem.verse: 4Let those who fear the Lord say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘His faithful love endures for ever.’

poem.verse: 5I called to the Lord in distress;

poetryblock.poem: the Lord answered me
and put me in a spacious place.

poem.verse: 6The Lord is for me; I will not be afraid.

poetryblock.poem: What can a mere mortal do to me?

poem.verse: 7The Lord is my helper;

poetryblock.poem: therefore, I will look in triumph on those who hate me.

poem.verse: 8It is better to take refuge in the Lord

poetryblock.poem: than to trust in humanity.

poem.verse: 9It is better to take refuge in the Lord

poetryblock.poem: than to trust in nobles.

poem.verse: 10All the nations surrounded me;

poetryblock.poem: in the name of the Lord I destroyed them.

poem.verse: 11They surrounded me, yes, they surrounded me;

poetryblock.poem: in the name of the Lord I destroyed them.

poem.verse: 12They surrounded me like bees;

poetryblock.poem: they were extinguished like a fire among thorns;
in the name of the Lord I destroyed them.

poem.verse: 13They pushed me hard to make me fall,

poetryblock.poem: but the Lord helped me.

poem.verse: 14The Lord is my strength and my song;

poetryblock.poem: he has become my salvation.

poem.verse: 15There are shouts of joy and victory

poetryblock.poem: in the tents of the righteous:
‘The Lord’s right hand performs valiantly!

poem.verse: 16The Lord’s right hand is raised.

poetryblock.poem: The Lord’s right hand performs valiantly! ’

poem.verse: 17I will not die, but I will live

poetryblock.poem: and proclaim what the Lord has done.

poem.verse: 18The Lord disciplined me severely

poetryblock.poem: but did not give me over to death.

poem.verse: 19Open the gates of righteousness for me;
